Take your time and take in the View.Only Downsisde is for anyone who cannot negotiate some stairs as to get to the Top Level you must be able to use stairs as well as the Elevator. They do warn you about this b$ you Pay.

Landmark of Tokyo. Despite Skytree is new landmark of Tokyo but Tokyo Tower is still the most gorgeous tower with its red painting. You need to pay entrance fee. You can take the JR train but take the subway the nearest station is Akabarebashi, it is just 5 mins walk from the station.We went there before lighting up, so you can view and take the scenery before and after, which gives you different feeling. Night scenery in Tokyo is stunning.
Tokyo's Eiffel Tower. This is a must see when in Tokyo. I was up here at night surveying Tokyo's skylights. It was breathtaking.
Tokyo tower. Tokyo tower was a nice place to go if you like to see an overview of the city which was really nice. Was told it is taller than the Eifel tower, but not as big around.

Good Tower. We were refused admission to the Tokyo Skytower and then gave up. Thank god we visited the old Tokyo Tower which probably gave better central views and didn't close, even though it was cloudy and wet the day we went up.

Interesting. Disappointed that 'One Asia Pass' was not readily known. After much perseverance, we were able to receive a 55th anniversary Tokyo Tower souvenir. Again, this was a whistle stop but we would not have missed it for all the world. We enjoyed the experience - very worthwhile indeed - a must visit.
Great view of the city. 55 year anniversary of the construction. Easy to get to by the subway. Views are incredible. Go on a clear day so you can see Mt Fuji.

Wonderful view. Superb view of Tokyo from above. Try to visit late afternoon to view the city then linger until Sun-down to experience the city 'lighting-up'. Tokyo Skytree is taller but considering the cost of going to the top of the Skytree for my money the Tower is quite high enough.
Great views across the City. Eiffel Tower in red a white. Great viewing of the entire City with glass windows in the floor to look through if you dare..... Nice shops and places to eat.

Great 360 view of Tokyo. The orange mini version of the Eiffel Tower. Its located in a nice suburb. Great place to have a good 360 view of Tokyo. It is also not expensive to get up to the observation deck and no crazy queue like Eiffel Tower.

More of a visual pleaser. Didn't really get a chance to sample this attraction properly as we arrived late in the day, and a fee is required to go to the top (however, I'm sure there are plenty of lovely views!).Instead we sampled the delights provided at the base; coffee shops, food stalls, shops selling overpriced tourist tat - the usual stuff really. Ok if you can get a really novel present for someone.Quite impressive when lit up in the evening though.

Nice view!. I know there's a new tower now... but at the time when I visisted, this was the only game in town. The view offered by the tower was great... the see through panels looking down... unnerving (not to me, but the wife was freaked out).Not as well connected to transit as I'd like, but still not too bad to get to.Definitely a must see in Tokyo.

Tokyo Tower, for those who love vintage. If you like aerial views, there are now a few options in the greater metro area, from Tokyo Tower, the granddaddy of them all, to the brand new Skytree in Oshiage and the Tokyo Metro Government buildings in Shinjuku and Landmark Tower in Yokohama's Sakuragicho/ Minato Mirai area as well. They are all towers. They provide views. But there are a few differences. If you prefer free, then choose Tokyo Govt Bldg, or if it is vintage for you, then go for Tokyo Tower with the added bonus of views of the Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo Bay. The Landmark Tower, shaped like a lighthouse, is all about the water, with the Minato Mirai area and Yokohama port, Yamashita park and the Bay Bridge within view. And if it is the latest and greatest you seek, then Skytree is for you.So pick a tower that fits your personality. And if you go on a weekend, expect it to be crowded.

Great place to see Tokyo. Great place to observe Tokyo in the morning, was cloudy we could not see Mount Fuji.I love to see architect and from this observation, you can easily watch Tokyo buildings. We could see skytree penetrating the clouds, that was a nice photo.You can pay for a photo service with a small tower model beside you. If you dont like to pay, They will also do the same with your own camera for free. Simple Souvenirs are available.

A Must See Landmark. While in Tokyo you really must hit up the important landmarks such as Tokyo Tower. It might not be as large or as new as Skytree (another must) but it is one of the symbols of Tokyo itself.
Stunning vista of nightime Toyko. Great view of nighttime Tokyo.. Tower has two levels. A ticket musts be purchase for each level. Cost for both levels was 16,000 yen.. Very crowded.

A must in Tokyo. So many reasons to visit this:- It's a symbol of Tokyo; hard to tell other people that you have been to Tokyo but not to the Tokyo tower.- It's easy to access by metro and it's just in the center of the city.- The ticket is not expensive.- The night view is GREAT.- The queue is not long and you can have dining on it (there is a restaurant/bar on it)Overall, it's difficult to find a reason to not go there at least once in your life time. :-)
really see Tokyo. The observation tower was worth the trip to see the panorama view of the city. go to both observation viewpoints to get the best views.

Gorgeous night view!. I had read a lot about Tokyo tower, but it wasn't on top of my to-dos. I noticed the tower while coming back from a dinner, and couldn't help walking towards it. The tower glows at night, and is a photographer's dream. As quick as it might be, the elevator ride to the top floor is quite thrilling. The tower closes at 9, 9.30ish so make sure you are there in time :)

Best views in Tokyo. For one of the best views over the whole city, if you are lucky with a low smog day, you will find it hard to beat this view. Spectacular glass floor for those not affected by heights

Iconic building and symbol of the city.. Scenic Tokyo tower is absolutely a must-see attraction. I went near the tower, I saw it up very close, I was astonished, it is fantastic. I wasn't able to climb to the top and enjoy the breathtaking spectacle, but I decided to admire it from below, this reminds me a little 'nowhere near the Eiffel Tower in Paris, but much smaller. In any case, a price ticket applied to get to the top. When the sun goes down it lights up and you can admire the spectacle from many parts of the city. absolutely not to be missed

So beautiful, especially at night when it changes colours a must see!. This beautiful tower took my breath away every time I saw it. So gorgeous you must visit it! At night it changes colours and truly is that beautiful. Don't go to japan without seeing this!
Fabulous. I really love this beautiful place Day and night view is perfectI used to celebrate my birthday every year, such a place to visit any season of the year and whenever you feel.... Great!

If you’re in the area it’s defiantly worth checking out.. You can either take an elevator to the main observation deck or walk up the stairs. My wife and I walked up the stairs and they gave us a small card saying that we used the stairs and how far it was. We didn’t get to go up to the top observation deck because it was going to be an hour and a half wait but the main one still had a great view of the surrounding area.

The Landmark of Tokyo. Tokyo Tower is one of the must see thing to do. It is one of Tokyo's most iconic sights. The view for the top is spectacular, you can see for miles. It is in close proximity of the city and all of the other attractions.

Awesome :). I really loved everything about it, at the base there are a lot of shop with a really big variety of item to buy and souvenir for everyone (from tshirt, to japanese lego, from knife for cut letters to awesome little Tokyo tower to gift friends when back at home). There a lot of food shops too and, if you really aren't too much into Japanese food there is even a Mac Donald there. Going up isn't much expensive and the photo you can make from there, they are just extraordinary. I lost almost half an hour just looking everywhere and trying recognise the place i've been in Tokyo so far. If you stay not many days in Tokyo be sure to put this on your absolutely TODO list :) You will not regret believe me!
Expansive view. A great way to take in the sights of this old and new city all inn one. You can se everything from traditional areas to the new modern Tokyo - that we all associate with the city.

Tokyo Tower. If you want to see the Eiffel Tower but are in Asia, not France, the Tokyo Tower is a close replica and close to other sights you will want to see All within walking distance. In the Tokyo tower you can ride to the top for a great view of Tokyo. Centrally located, you can walk to all of the shopping areas, see the last grounds of the Tokugawa Shogunate, walk throughout the headstones of those that built Japan during the period of peace prior to the Meiji Restoration. If you have to have an American Burger, there are many along the walk to stop for both American and Japanese cuisine. Close to the Railroad and Subway lines, I highly recommend a walking tour to see the Tokyo Tower as well as the many other sights along the way. Many Japanese Dramas have as their backdrop, the Tokyo Towers. Great to see during the daytime or night time. I will add photos we took as I lower their resolution.

Landmark in the City of Tokyo. Tokyo Tower (東京タワー, 東京鐵塔) was the highest tower in Japan until the new Tokyo Skytree opened in 2012. The purpose of the tower was for TV and radio transmission just like the new Tokyo Skytree. Its design was based on the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France. The construction started in 1957 and was completed in 1958. It opened to the public on December 23, 1658. The orange and white colors make the Tokyo Tower stand out from a far distance. It is now the 2nd highest structure in Japan. This lattice tower is made of steel just like the Eiffel Tower, but its 333 m (1,093 ft) height makes it taller than the Eiffel Tower’s 324 meters (1,063 ft) tall and used far less materials. Its primary purpose was for television broadcasting. Since the digital era is coming and the tower is not high enough due to the development of Tokyo, the new Tokyo Skytree (634 m / 2,080 ft) took over its purpose. Tokyo Tower is now used for broadcasting Japanese media outlets. We walked from the subway station and visited the Tokyo Tower in the morning because we already saw the night scene at the Tokyo Skytree. The first time we visited Tokyo Tower was about 8 years ago, and we only had a vague memory. We loved to visit it again. 2014 is its 55th anniversary. We purchased tickets that included both the Main Observatory and Special Observatory. The two-story Main Observatory is located at 150 meters (490 ft), while the smaller Special Observatory reaches a height of 250 meters (820 ft). At the observatory, people enjoyed the view of Tokyo through the windows. Although it was sunny, it was not clear enough to see far distances. On the Main Observatory, we found the glass “Lookdown Window”. We took photos right through the window, and it was amazing. Just like all indoor observatories, the reflection from the glass might be a problem for taking photos. We did not spend the time to visit the lower 4-story building – FootTown. There were not many visitors. It might be because the new Tokyo Skytree attracts most of the tourists. The bright orange / white color makes it stands out in Tokyo skyline, and it certainly is the most important landmark in the city of Tokyo.You can take the Hibiya Line and get off at Kamiyacho Station (神谷町). It takes about 10 to 15 minutes by foot. Tokyo Tower is located on a small hill, and the last few walks were good exercise – especially on a hot, sunny day. It opens year-round, and the admission is ¥1,600 (both the Main Observatory + Special Observatory) for adult. You can visit their website for more information.
Tokyo Tower. I maanged to get to the top level for sunset and it was worth hogging a spot at the west window to watch this wonder.

BEAUTIFUL. Beautiful TOWER
Very Nice View
The best place in Tokyo!
I LOVE IT!!!
I am always happy when i go here!!!

Had a good time here!. Aside from the scenery, lots of local shopping that can be done here. Lots of restaurants and bakeries on the premises. Easy access from the metro and close to Asakusa street markets. We spent almost a day here.

If u come to Tokyo must visit here.. Exist at akabanebashi station(赤羽桥）walk around 10mins pass by a petrol station and walk straight. I saw in the information is saying about walking distance 3mins . Actually is more than that. The ticket is adult ¥900 ,buying ticker at level 1 . There is a lot souvenir shop at level2 and have a live music show when u at the main viewing place , and cafe.
Just what it stands for. A great look out over the city, and Some shops at the bottom, restaurants and a lot of officies. Manhattan in tokyo

Great views of a huge city. This tower is a fantastic icon, I've seen it from many locations in Tokyo and finally went up to see the views which were absolutely stunning, my god I knew Tokyo was big but these views puts everything into perspective, when in Tokyo you must see this and the breathtaking views of one of the biggest cities in the world.
Big City. Big.. I wanted a sky view of Tokyo so we visited Tokyo Tower. A bit of a walk, but incredible to see how expansive the city is. More reasonable than Sky Tower.
Good views. During the day the tower looks like a TV mast but in the evening the tower looks amazing! Also the view is great and this combined with night view is something worth seeing.

Tokyo Tower. This was a very unexpected site for me to visit in Tokyo. The tower was several blocks from my brother's apartment so I could see it everyday. It is beautiful lit up at night and a fun place to visit and see the views from the top. It is also a great landmark which helped me to keep my bearings when walking around the area.

Great nightview. In the evening the Tower itself looks amazing! Also the view is great but combined with lighted Tokio Tower it's something worth seeing.Unfortunately you may also expect long queues...

Nice views, go to the upper levels. This is a good way to view Tokyo from above is you want to avoid the queues of places like Tokyo Sky Tree (which is also amazing). I recommend going to the upper levels to see the most of Tokyo. Who goes to an observation deck to only go halfway? It was a misty day when I went but could still see quite far. My only complaint is not the tower itself, but the aquarium at the base of it. I would avoid this at all costs. I've seen fish in pet shops kept in better conditions. There where big 4ft fish crammed into 3ft tanks with no place to swim. No plants or gravel/sand in the tanks. I used to keep fish myself and actually left this 'aquarium' feeling quite upset.

Go all the way up!. A friend who lives in Tokyo took me their and confessed that he usually takes girls on the second date to this special place. The view from the tower is truly astonishing. Don't be cheap and stay on only half the hight. Go all the way and enjoy a view that is easily one of the most impressive ones you'll ever have. When seeing skyscrapers and light all around you until the horizon you start to get a feeling how big a 35 million inhabitant metropolitan area is.

Basic city from above experience. This was something we do during every trip, to see the city from above. Access to this place was easier than to the Skytree which would have been higher, but was always closed due to wind when we came there. If memory serves, price for the visit was quite expensive in comparison to the actual experience.

Great views of the city. The Tower provides breathtaking views of the city. It is worth the money to pay to go to the upper level. The views are even better. Be sure to stand on the glass and gaze far down to the ground below. Take pictures of your feet on the glass so your friends can appreciate the height.

Now I know how massive Tokyo is. My wife and I went to see the tower at night time around 9pm. We debated acutally going up as it costs 900 Yen (which really isn't that bad). We're glad we decided to do it in the end because the view of the city is incredible. We didn't really understand just how massive Tokyo was until we saw a 360 degree view of wall-to-wall buldings as far as the eye could see.

Swords at Tokyo Tower. We visted Tokyo Tower on 9th July. The view at night is fantastic. It was quite crowded and we had to queue to get to the observatory. The shopping was excellent and the food court had many choices.We were happily surprised when we found a gift shop that had "tourist" swords for sale. We purchased a replica Katana, Wakizashi and sword stand for 18,000 yen. We had seen similar swords and stands for double this price at two other locations.My son was extremely happy, and the swords are our best souvenir of Japan...besides the great memories of people and travel.

Amazing view of the city at night!. Amazing place outside and inside, My suggestion is to visit the tower at night. The only complain I have is that is a long walk from the nearest station, but is worth! Not too much crowd

Go to the top!. We took the JR train and walked a bit to get to the tower. Although the day was still a bit hazy, we paid to go all the way to the top. It was worth the extra bit as you could get an totally above view of the buildings. Mt. Fuji wasn't viewable (sad), but there was plenty more to see! When you exit there is a little exhibit (in Japanese) about the tower. It was interesting to see pictures of the tower being built. There was also a small food court and shopping.
Lovely views over Tokyo. the view of Tokyo by night was amazing. Views can be enjoyed from every corner- 360 degree view. price is more.
Wonderful views over Tokyo.. No walking lifts everywhere. This was great for us. Great for people with walking difficulties We liked this tour
Lovely views!. Orderly well controlled crowd & all the facilities available at the site.It has lovely views of the bustling & most populous city in the world!

Worth the long walk!. It's quite a long trek from the nearest station when you're trying to find your way there at night.
Very pretty at night with all the lights!
It's a little old since they now have Tokyo skytree, but this is the the less crowded version

Great at night!. We went with our two young children an evening. All of us loved it. It wasn't too crowded at night, and the view of Tokyo by night was amazing. Take your time and enjoy the view from every side...
Awesome View. I've been to the Eiffel Tower and Tokyo Tower. Both are equally beautiful. Be sure to bring a camera! Must see attraction during your visit to Tokyo.

Magnificent view. Because of the colour, it may seem a bit of 'an eyesore' when you first spot it.Then, as you get nearer you start to appreciate its architecture. When you finally get inside and up to the highest observation deck, you can enjoy a superb, unrivaled 360 degree view of the city, truly stunning especially at sunset. Stayed there until late at night and had a nice dinner, too.

now it is very nice. everybody is heading to the skytree -now you dont wait in endless queues, you have room to wander arround and you can hold and watch the magnificient landscape -we were there at 6.pm which is almost an ideal time as you can watch the sun set and the night view- if yo ustay a bit. the restaurant (coffee and ice cream mainly ) is very resonable -so enjoy
Nice night views but overpriced. The views were very nice at night from the two observation decks, but it is overpriced for what it is. Try and use a discount voucher if you get your hands on one.

Great views. It provides great views of Tokyo at two different floors. We went mid July and no rows to go up. It took a maximum of 10 minutes since we bought the tickets till we reached the top. Excellent customer service

On a clear day. A good option to the sky tree and much cheaper. What does 100 metres or so matter? I went midweek and the crowds weren't bad at all. I opted to go to the special observation deck. So 250m rather than 150m. It was worth it, though if it was busy it would be a long wait as the lift can only take 10 at a time. The views are fantastic, though dependant on the weather. On my visit there was either a haze or smog hanging over the outer reaches of the city which impeded the view somewhat but not dramatically. Very close to the Zojoji Temple so you can easily do both.
A great view. We loved the view from the top level. We got there just before dusk and watched the sunset. Spectacular!

Can't miss it. Wow, one of the few places with great signage to get there. I really enjoyed my visit here, there is a bunch of souvenir shops at ground level along with about 6 restaurants serving in the smallish food court. The 800 yen takes you about half way up to an indoor observation platform and for an extra 600 you can go pretty much to the top, I just did the half way level. Once inside a robot points out points of interest trouble was that everytime a human got within a certain distance he stopped talkinga nd moving, and children loved to touch him. I gave up on the robot and used the interactive screens which show landmarks and distances. I could easily see Disneyland and Skytree from here. A nice afternoon visit it may be even better at night when the city lights up.
Awesome views. My son and I really enjoyed the views and the customer service was friendly and very inviting! given the choice between this and the Sky tree though the sky tree views were AMAZING!

Worth a visit. It is a great way to see across the whole of Tokyo. Unfortunately the weather was not good while I was there, but it is still impressive to go up and see Tokyo extend outwards for as far as the eye can see. It cost ¥820 to get to the main observation deck with the option to purchase another ticket once there for ¥600 to get to the higher deck (you have to walk).

Not really the best observation point in the city. I guess that landmark is a little overrated. There's no ability to enjoy view not through the window (which has a lot of scratches). The view is fine - just like from the other skyscrapers. I've been to several observation points in Tokyo, so I'd recommend you to go to Roppongi tower - there you can walk right on top of the roof on an open deck (which is helicopter parking) and enjoy a great view (the building stands on the top of the hill) and also there's a nice bars where you can sip a wine while watching Mount Fuji.

Great Views. Well worth a visit just for the amazing views of the city. We were lucky as it was not too busy. Nice cafe bar to relax and enjoy the sights and people watch. On Sunday there is free entertainment.On the ground floor there are shops and restaurants.Pick a clear day to go.

Elegance and serenity with live jazz at night!. Take the subway to the southern stations and then walk to the Tower. Do it at night, you will pass parks and streets lined with shadows of shrines and trees. Tokyo is so safe and silent at night you can sense a relaxed environment. In the reception grab a ticket and enter the elevator. There is a hostess in it and you will have no clue what she is saying if Japanese is not in your roots, but this is part of the fun of being here! The elevator is so fast, after all, it's Japan! Once in the first observation deck, the view is secured by windows. The view is mesmerizing and you feel the power of this capital but also the serenity that it has during the night. There are 2 small floor windows so you can see through to the street. The cherry on the pie was a live jazz concert the same night I went there (not sure but I think they do it twice a week). The band was playing near the cafetería and I happen to just stare at the tall buildings and streets lights under a serene and elegant atmosphere. Just like Japan: simple, elegant and serene. Enjoy.
"a must visit". it's 20-30 minutes walking distance from Hamamatsucho Station via JR, worth the walk as it's such a beauty at night view!
Pity it was raining. We did a Tokyo morning tour which included the Tokyo tower, unfortunately it was raining so the views were not great.
Terrific view. Well worth a visit.Lift to first observation deck,steps to the top.Great view over Tokyo.Glass panels over sheer drops on first observation deck.Sit and chill at the Cafe.
Beautiful. When it was lit up at night. Affordable and good views. Like the Eiffel tower only red and white. Close to the subway.

A Great View of Tokyo. While I'm sure the experience cannot be very much different from other like towers, I definitely think Tokyo Tower is worth going to just for appreciating Tokyo as a whole city. Looking out from the observation decks, you get a real sense of just how amazingly huge (and new-looking) this wonderful city is. It is a really 'touristy' thing to do, but worth it. Plus there are lots of little gift-shop stands in the building where you can buy souvenir gifts.

Good view of Tokyo city. Nothing great on the tower, if you have seen similar ones in other cities. Its in the shape of Paris Eiffel tower. The lift was fast to the roof top and a great view of the Tokyo city. There is also a see through where there is glass window to see the bottom of the tower to its length from the top. You can buy souvenirs at the roof top. When driving past the tower in the night, it had a great look. One of the must visit site in Tokyo.

Excellent View at Night. Tokyo is a city where people works in the day time and enjoy themselves in the evening. It is true that Tokyo Tower comes alive after sunset. The beauty of the tower when it is lidded up. Approaching the tower with its sight is awesome. Once inside and elevated to the first level, the view of Tokyo city is exciting and worth the visit. To further elevation is up to the choice of the visitor but the line can be long.

Nice view. Great view to show the VASTNESS that is Tokyo. Easy to find, the higher view is worth the money to me, the lower view was too low. $14 for both tickets. You buy the lower ticket, then when you get to that level you can buy the ticket to the upper deck.

Definitely Go at Night. Tokyo Tower provides awesome views of city, but the tower is especially gorgeous at night when it's all lit up night. The 360 degree views of Tokyo are excellent but like its counterpart, The Tokyo Skytree, DO NOT pay to go to the top level. The lines are long and the views are exactly the same. It's a waste of money and time. They said, the views from the first level is worth every penny. My family loved it.

Great Panoramic View of Tokyo. Tokyo Tower gives a terrific overview on the history and development of Tokyo. I particularly loved the interactive monitor in visitors can get a very good sense on what the city was like during Edo and Meiji eras. Visitors can put down a refundable deposit to rent the binoculars. My family, particularly, my two kids, found the binoculars helpful.
Touristy. Tokyo Tower is a pale shadow of the Eiffel Tower. It is touristy but does offer great views from the top platform. Going to the medium platform only probably is not worthwhile.
Classic !. The tower is worth a visit but i still obviously prefer sky tree. And the tower is worth a visit because it's classic. And prices are not over rated

great views. this is a nice place to visit and see all of Tokyo .. its very organized and everyone seems to speak very good english. All the staff are extremely helpful and kind.. its well worth a visit.
Old but classic. Skytree may catch everyone's eyes, but the classic always be there.You can buy a more cheaper ticket to get on to Tokyo Tower and have a better view there.Really good at night.
Cool, but disappointing. The top of the tower gives a great view of tokyo 360 degrees. Unfortunately, the expense offsets it. The glass floor is more like a small square. Wouldn't go again.

Good views over business district.. Nothing to rave about - just a good view over this particular area of Tokyo.
Usual tacky souvenirs for sale and hoards of school parties evident when we went up.
Interesting temple nearby is worth a visit.

Beautiful..must visit. This is simply beautiful and the view from top is spectacular and that is valid only till you visit the sky tree and go to the 450th floor :-). The place is open till 9PM and it is best to visit at night when the lights are on. There are some good food joints inside the Tokyo tower and is worth trying. There are also plenty of snack counters and you can buy the popular sweet Tokyu Banana here....you don't get it in most of the shops and is worth a try.
View-full. One gets a lovely city view (on a clear day) from the top of this communication tower. However, the glass floor is a little small!
Incredible, amazing, beautiful. It is spectacular, beautiful and it is very nice to walk around, then go up to an amazing view of the city. In a clear day you can see Mount Fuji really well.

Quite an impressive sight. Visited the tower on Monday June 2 and it was very crowded....will go again and apply for ticket....plenty of restaurants and attractions all around the tower...very well organized.

A little Eiffel. See if you have time and it's an icon of Tokyo so see it but if you miss it do not feel bad. Good views but we were there on a cloudy day. 1958 it was the tallest tower in Japan and it's not that tall. Maybe it's great in the evening with all the lights.
Tokyo Tower. Great way to convert communication tower into a city icon and tourist attraction..! This tower is inspired by Eifel tower . One must visit it in evening to see it in full glory.

A must do. Really recommend visiting on a cleanish day, the views are incredible. Ideally visit late afternoon so can enjoy in daylight, watch sunset and arguably the best view is Tokyo and Yokohama at night. Stunning.

Basically the Eiffel Tower in Japan. The difference is there are 3 levels in France and you can walk outside - here it's only 2 level and it's all enclosed.I suppose this has basically been replaced by Sky Tree, but this is cheaper and the lines are likely to be shorter. There is a large shrine nearby which is nice to visit at the same time too.I visited the area a few times while I worked there without actually going up, as the area is nice to walk around.

Tokyo Tower a MUST!. Great few hours spent at the Tokyo Tower and surrounding area. A lift takes you up to the 1st drop off point, can fully appreciate & enormous breadth & depth of Tokyo as you walk around the 360degrees view glass windowed vantage points. Take a lift for the 2nd stop (not for the faint hearted or scared of heights people!!) to experience a bird's eye view from atop the Tower! Amazing and the ONLY way to see how spread out Tokyo is & "what is where" compared to Tokyo Bay & the famous Rainbow Bridge! Well worth a visit!

Disappointing. Tokyo Tower is a brightly colored scale replica of the Eiffel Tower. I don't think it's worth the time and money to go inside. Tokyo is almost permanently covered in smog so that the view of the skyline is fuzzy and it is a very rare day indeed when you can see Mount Fuji. Also there isn't that much to do around Tokyo Tower. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building in Shinjuku has a view that is just as good (or bad) but it is free. Also there is plenty to do in Shinjuku so it will not be a wasted trip even if the view disappoints. However the view of the Tokyo Tower can be pretty from the outside. I think the best view would be from the lobby of the Mitsui Garden Hotel in Ginza. The coffee shop there also has very good ice cream.
Top of Tokyo Tower Thrill. Brace yourself for an adventure worth the thrill. A violin concert at the top of Tokyo tower nailed it. Really fascinating and 'vertigo-less' ride.
go higher to see more. Have a 360 degree view to tokyo city. Many key buildings as well as Rainbow Bridge can be seen. It's worth taking lift to 250m observatory deck for excellent view.

Best View here!. Incredible view, a must do day or night. Both have advantages, so i would recommend, day for first time in Tokyo. This will give you a good perspective of how big this city is, and if you a guide or local, Many attractions can be identified.But if you are only going once, got to go at night, stunning view.

Best Tokyo view. It's in a nice neighbourhood. This red/orange paint gives this place unforgettable charm.And glass floor windows are much bigger then in the new tower.Top floor brings me back Empire States building feeling.Oh and children love it!

This beats Tokyo Skytree. After visiting both the Tokyo Skytree and Tokyo Tower, I have to say that I absolutely love the Tokyo Tower. The reason is that it's a lot less crowded and way more romantic. The view was clearer than Tokyo Skytree. It's also very convenient to other popular locations; akihabra and tsukiji market. I highly recommend the Tokyo Tower over the Tokyo Skytree. Definitely worth the visit!

Worth a visit. It's not exactly the Eiffel, but comes pretty close. However, you can only go up to the middle of the tower where the viewing deck is, not all the way to the top. Highly recommend joining a day tour if it's your first time to Tokyo.

good for have tokyo view. we had a half day tokyo s/s tour organised by hato bus..!!! we have reached to the half of the observatory deck... view was really nice with all big skyscrappers & at very far if weather permitts then you can able to view mt. fuji...!!observatory deck have glass windows at the bottom surface so you can have a stunning view of roads with tiny people moving around..!! there are food outlets at the deck...overall good experience..-- visited on nov 2009

Off to the top deck!. I've been here twice now, the first time we were to cheap to to go to the top and I was underwhelmed. I only when back the second time because a friend was visiting and this time we went all and way up and I have to say that the veiw were much better and well worth th few extra yen.

Not so exciting. Fine if you like skyline towers. It looks stunning lit up at night. On a morning in month of May I went to the top but it was a foggy misty day and impossible to more than a few feet away from windows. I was told that Mount Fuji can be seen on a clear day so disappointed not to see anything at all. The lift goes fast to the top where there is a cafe and a souvenir shop. There were other places I would have preferred to visit in the short time available on tour if I had been given a choice.

... and my legs turned to jelly when I sat on the glass looking directly below.. all 240m of it. Compared to other such similar viewing extravaganzas i.e. Taipei 101, Empire State Building, the Tokyo Tower was ok. Sure, we could see some wonderful views of Tokyo from that height but somehow, it felt rather non-event.On the downside, I thought that it was very commercial. I thought there would be some introspection on how the tower was built and how it can withstand the earthquakes Japan is known for... but nope, none of that. They just wanted to sell me water bottles in the shape of the tower.... -.-

Stunning at night. We saw it at day and it looked good but then we went back to see it at night and it was stunning. It is a bit out of the way and you need to change trains to reach here but worth it.
amazing at night. Tried to see the tower from Roppongi side (Mori tower) and you will see the whole tower nicer from different angle.
Beautiful view of Tokyo. Going up to the upper observatory was the best experience I had on my short trip to Tokyo.If you love photography this is great place to take good ones.

Stunning views. Tokyo tower is a real must if you're in Japan. The 360 degree views of Tokyo from the top are stunning.and we are so glad we made the effort in our very short break to the city to squeeze it in. We arrived late afternoon but stayed until dusk as the view at night is magical.

Not very original but a great view. The Tokyo Tower is like an ugly Eiffel Tower and there's not much inside that is worth the trouble (you forget you're in Japan, actually) but you will be led there inevitabily if you book a tour of Tokyo. Make the most of it and enjoy the sights on top of the Tower. You will find some interesting Japanese highlights on what at first sight seems to be a Westernized city. If you don't have a tour booked, however, and are out on your own, skip it and try a Japanese tea house instead or simply walking around one of many public gardens. If you get lost, the locals will help you out. They are extremely courteous.

Great Views, Must-Visit for Tokyo. Great place to take in spectacular views of the city. Go at night for great views of the cityscape. There were lots of people there, but they seemed to have an efficient system setup, so the wait was very reasonable.

great view. really enjoyed our night view across the city. excellent interactive display screens. luckily it was a crystal clear evening and we sat to have a drink at the bar on the lower level which also had live music .

The old attraction, but a short walk from Roppongi. It`s now the old attraction, as the new one is the Sky Tree, but still worth a visit, as its a short walk from Roppongi, or even to compare to the new Sky Tree - a generation or more difference, and the difference does show, but this Arc de Triomphe copy is worth a visit in its own right. Great for a sky view of Tokyo.

The spitiy symbol of Japan. It just so beautiful to look it from far. It looks just like the Paris Effie Tower! When you go up there, you see the beautiful night view of core Japan, Tokyo. I like it so much. You should go to towers around it to take pictures of Tokyo Tower and go up there in a separate day. In that case, you can see both views in great blue background.It's also spirit symbol of Japan. It representing the technology Japan has. Also, there are just so many romantic Japanese drama around Tokyo. You should try to watch some before going!!

Not just a tower, a piece of art!. Instantly recognized as a icon, a symbol of Tokyo, the Tower is indeed worth a personal visit. Today it is a tourist destination, in the past the tower was an important piece of Japanese broadcasting technology. Built in 1959 and remarkably similar to the Eiffel Tower (1889) in Paris, France. The tower's two observation decks offer stunning views of the city.I really enjoyed my first visit here, but less so later visits (once you see it, there not a lot compelling a return visit)It stands at 333m tall, and is the second tallest structure in Japan, after the Tokyo Skytree (634m) which was built to replace the Tokyo Tower for HDTV Digital Television broadcasting.In more recent years the four story building at the base, called "Foot Town" has become a tourist attraction (Wax Museum, Guinness Records photos, the Trick Art gallery, and a small theme park on the roof) obviously to cater to the families and younger visitors.

Worth a visit. This place is awesome and way better to visit than the Tokyo Skytree. It's not as new, is right next to the Zojo-ji temple (which is amazing, by the way), and far less crowded with almost no wait to get to the top. Great views! There's a small amount of shopping here and food for purchase but not that much. Note that we were hoping to see Mount Fuij but unfortunately the haze in the distance obscured the view as apparently it sometimes does. The rest of the views were great though.

Second choice but a good one. We went to Tokyo Skytower not once but twice in two days but could not believe the queue that we had to go through. Hence we decided to forgo Tokyo Skytower and opted to go to Tokyo Tower. And it was a good choice in the end as it was less crowded, accessible by subway too. It also provided a nice point to see Tokyo skyline by dusk to nighttime. All is well that ends well.

Wonderful. Great view, wonderful tower, souvenirs at the tower. Bus trip from hotel, but got dropped off at train station, very busy, frightening, had to try and find our way back to hotel from under ground, lucky a man took us to our hotel

Stunning view of Tokyo. One of the place I've always wanted to visit since I'm a teenager. I visited here on November 2007, I remember there was a Christmas themed park around the entrance of it with a big christmas tree with many pretty lights on it.I arrived there around 5pm, so I still can get the view of the city while there's still sun, I can see the mountain Fuji from afar, then see the sunsets and watch the whole city slowly turns their structures into breathtaking glowing city of lights down below.the middle observatory level is very wide, the interactive widescreen on each corner works great by helping us to figure out which famous areas are we looking at on every direction, there's also some of those coin-powered-binocular-stands you can use if you want to peek a close look on the city. There's also a cozy cafe in it, that's where we mostly spent time watching for sunset until it's fully dark, then I move to the top level observation deck using the lift (wait around for 10 minutes in queue). the top level observation deck is narrower then the one below, but it gives you even a better look of the sparkling city. But I gotta say the top level is more "romantic" than the one below that is more suitable for families with children as they can roam around better than on the top level deck.Below the tower, there's a small complex of food booths you can visit to grab some grub (I had one of the most delicious pizza here! I think it's called pizzeria or something) and souvenir shop of Tokyo tower.

Not a must see.... Given the number of times I've seen the Tokyo Tower in mangas, animes and movies, I felt it was worthwhile to pay pilgrimage to this icon.In all fairness, the tower met my expectations and looked exactly as I have imagined it from the ground level. And while the views were good from both the main and upper observation levels, I felt the time and money could have been better spent exploring other attractions in Tokyo. Unlike Hong Kong, New York, etc. there really wasn't much of a concentrated skyline to see here, and so it lacked the 'wow' factor one would expect from an attraction. In my opinion, you won't lose much from not going up the tower.

Red Eiffel Tower. My friend and I visited this on our 2nd trip to Japan and it was just OK. There's a fee going up halfway and of course going to the topmost part is more expensive. We went there to take pictures, and that's it. We arrived at almost sunset time so we were able to see it without and with the lights on.

Hard to rate. This one is hard to rate. It is just like you might think, it is Tokyo trying to imitate the Eiffel Tower (which we just did 6 months prior), and not measuring up. Wish we'd done the Sky Tower instead. It's a nice view of the city, but then, the city does not have a memorable sky-scape. It is NOT worth the wait to go to the higher level (another imitation of Eiffel). You will not be more impressed by the wait or the extra fee. Nice to do if you have extra time, but, again, we hear that the Sky Tower is the thing to do.
Walla muuaa. Just look on the picture how pretty its .magnificent piece of art like everything in Japan from bottom to top my bes advice go at night to see it sparkling like a diamond.
Amazing View!. My husband and I recently visited Tokyo and listed Tokyo Tower as a "must see." The 360° view from the top of the tower is absolutely amazing!

Had a good couple of hours here. Visited with my wife and two sons (one a baby and one was four at the time) last month. Well worth a visit. The tower has some great views of Tokyo; not as impressive as what we saw up the Tokyo Skytree but still very good views. We saw a show outside the tower - a guy had a monkey doing all sorts of tricks (backflips, walking on his hands etc) which our oldest boy absolutely loved. It was incredible. We would recommend a visit here

Overshadowed by the SkyTree. I visited this attraction way back in 2004. Back then I found it an enjoyable visit, with good views over Tokyo, especially from the top observation deck. The tower was full of trinkets and souvenirs, but little else. And the immediate surrounding area had little going for it. Nevertheless I did enjoy my time there.Unfortunately, it has now been overshadowed by the SkyTree, which provides for a superior viewing experience (if far, far busier). As such, what would have initially been a 4-star review is now only a 3-star. One interesting view that I have not experienced is that of the SkyTree from Tokyo's 'Eiffel' Tower. I have seen vice versa, and managed to capture both towers in the same photo when visiting the Metropolitan Building in Shinjuku.All in all, if you are passing through the area and it is a clear day it would be worth your while, but I wouldn't recommend a specific visit otherwise.(And apologies for the poor quality of the photos!)

Very Imposing. It looks like a small version of the Eiffel Tower, painted a red-orange color. On a clear day, you get a good view of Tokyo and sometimes Mt. Fuji. Personally, I think the elevator ride up is scary and would not want to be on top during a quake.

Worth going high at Tokyo Tower. The Tokyo Tower is really quite a tall structure, rivalling the Eiffel Tower in height as well as looks. You can go to the 150m main Observation Deck for 820 yen or to the special 250m deck for 1420. Go high; it takes you above the tower blocks of Tokyo so you see a great deal more of the city. There's a pleasant café n the main deck.

Nice to see from afar. Don't fall into the trap of paying to go up the tower, if you want to see views of Tokyo - head to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government office instead as it's free. :) The tower is good to look at from afar but if you've been to say, the Eiffel Tower, then this tower may be a bit of a disappointment.

Tokyo Tower. Beautiful setting near the Zojo-ji Temple. Lights up magnificently in the sky at night becoming a beacon to its location. Situated near Zojo-ji there is the opportunity to have the old and new Japan combine. Access to the toweris well organized and provides a great view over Tokyo. On a clear day Mt Fuji can be sighted. Many shops and eateries are located in the base of the tower providing the chance to buy souvenirs from the location.

Great view.. Worth seeing Tokyo from both the main observatory 250m and special 350m. Went there on the evening and can highly recommend it. Great view over Tokyo. Even Rainbow bridge can be seen fairly close.The tower is lit up until 22.00, waiting for the lights to go out was not worth it. Unless you just happen to go that time don't wait for it.Also there are some souvenir shops and food court downstairs to take a quick peek at before leaving.
To be done. The view is excellent, go to the top! The last elevator is a bit scary but the view worth the detour. I really enjoy viewing how big is Tokyo and see high buildings around.

All of Tokyo at one time.... It's like the tower in Paris. Go all the way to the top - it cost a bit more but how many times will you be there? You can see all of Tokyo and sometimes you can even see Fuji~!! Tokyo Tower is a must-see spot when visiting Tokyo.

Great View!. For vacation me and my husband booked a tour through Hato bus and one of the stops was Tokyo Tower. On the lower floors there are a few places to purchase souvenirs, but of course you come to take in the view. The view was very nice. Sometimes on clear days you can see mount Fuji in the distance, but beware, unless the weather is good you may not see it due to sky conditions. There is an elevator all the way up, but getting down can be a bit confusing, as you have to go to the 3rd floor and then walk down the rest of the way. Overall, don't miss this if you can. Bigger than the Eiffel Tower by a few meters, it definitely gives you an idea of how giant Tokyo really is from the top.
Very nice. This is one of the landmark, so why not go there? Nice view, nice experience. If you go up you can see nice view if tokyo. Have a good time!

Affordable thing to do in Tokyo. Visited here over Golden Week in Japan. Great views of all of Tokyo. Cheap to get to the first level at 150 meters. Recommend taking the elevator up and the stairs down. Only 600 steps. Can be done in 6 minutes. 820 yen ticket. 600 yen more if you want to go to the top at 250 meters. There is a very nice Temple nearby you should see as well.

Tokyo must see sightseeing. Came here at morning to take a photo and short walk near tokyo tower theres a temple - not know what temple it is - but take a picture there and its really beautiful. Must go at night too, the view is so amazing - even if ur not go upstairs - looking for the tower itself at night is so beautiful scenery. Go to tokyo but not go to tokyo tower? Seems something missed.

Very nice view. This copy of the Eiffel Tower offers a very nice view over the city. You can get to two levels and ought to take it all the way to the top level, even though that may mean a bit of queuing (nothing compare to the Sky tree!). Even though the Sky tree is much more popular, I do think you get a better view of the city centre than here. So take advantageous of not having to book beforehand.There is an option to shop and get a refreshment there, but below that opportunity is even better. I went for tasty noodle which was really a nice experience. So combining it with a meal is good option s well.

Beautiful at night!. We went to the large observation area late afternoon to see the sunset and watch the traffic leaving the main part of the city. It is quite unique to look down of the crazy streets of the city.
Great views. Closer to the action than it's shiny new sister, there are great views (saw Mt Fuji) in every direction at a good price. And no way near as busy as the Skytree.
Go at night for good views. Great views at night. Price isn't bad, but also consider using the Tokyo Met Government building for free views of Tokyo.
Worth a look. Great to take a look at this, both from the ground and from the top. Good views, pity I was in a rush and couldn't stay long.

Worth a visit. Tokyo Tower isn't exactly the best, or biggest, or shiniest place you can to while in Tokyo. But it still deserves a visit if you go there for the first time and have some time available.It's like the Eiffel Tower, true, but the neighborhood is very disappointing, small and gray houses, hills and a lot of big roads. Anyway the Tower stands above all this, and approaching to it (it sits on a small hill) is still impressive if made after sunset.Probably it's too expensive to go up to the observatory (go to the Skytree or Mori Tower instead), but the overall "vintage" feeling of the souvenirs shops and restaurants inside can bring you back to a 1970-80s Japan. And that's why the Tokyo Tower deserves a visit.

Great views...... One of the classical must do's in Tokyo. The view from the top platform is similar to Ski tree, and more conveniently located. So much to do around TT within taxi distance. However, if you want to have a great meal (very expensive-reservations required), with a spectacular view, than Sky tree should be your choice. Cross your fingers that the weather is clear.
Great view!. Recommend this tower for your first time visit to Tokyo with perfect view of the city. I bought many boxes of Tokyo Banana there, so good!
Nice views. Visited this place as part of the afternoon tour of Tokyo. At 40-storeys high, you have 360 view of Tokyo and its surroundings

Tokyo goes on and on and on . . .. From the Tokyo Tower, you really get a sense of just how vast the city is . . . how it goes on in every direction. We were lucky, too -- the weather was clear and we had a great view of Mt. Fuji.

Tokyo Tower. Tokyo tower is well worth to visit,locals and many people from all over the world flooded to view.it is also good to take some pictures, you will not regret visiting the place. Plus a lot of gifts shops for those who will need to take souvenir to those at home.

expensive but exclusive view of tokyo. new attraction in tokyo. it is the second largest structure in the world. you can go up to 450 mts. it is a bit overpriced but well for once in a lifetime unique experience to observe the grandeur of tokyo

Diminutive now, yet a nice experience. While tokyo sky tree may give you a better view of tokyo, if you are in Minato area do go here, as this is much less crowded, the look down window gives a much better view (I think!) and overall more of a place for a leisurely time. Well that's what I holiday for!
Tokyo Tower. Been there many times. Always fun! Lots of people, tourists and locals. Take your time while your there. Shoot some pics. And just take in the view.

Tokyo Tower. Tokyo Tower is well worth the visit - easily reached on foot from central Tokyo. Great views all around - make sure you go to the top level - this is an additional cost but you won't regret it. Souvenir shops have plenty on offer as gifts for those at home.

レトロいや新しい？（History of structure). The Tokyo tower was built in 1950's. The target opening day was 3rd of March 1958. The Japanese calendar said that day was 3 3 33. The height of tower is 333 m. The tower is made of steel plates, and the connection method is either bolting nor welding. The tower was made by rebutting method. It has been repainted simultaneously. The constant maintenance work is the key point of beauty of tower. The night view is also beautiful because the illumination and the light up are make up her appearance.

For a change walk down. It has been a few years since I visited Tokyo Tower and it has been largely superseded by the new Sky-Tree across the Sumida River from Asakusa, Mt. Fuji etc. but it is much less crowded, and no reservations are required, on a clear view has a great view of Tokyo, Haneda Airport, and down to Yokohama. You can walk there from Hamamatsucho Station on the Yamanote Line, it is an uphill walk but not particularly steep. And as an added side attraction the route from the station to the tower skirts, or you can walk through the grounds of Zenchou-ji Temple one of the largest in Tokyo, it is a concrete reproduction as the original was burned in the late unpleasantness between the U.S. and Japan. Never the less it is worth strolling through, the original main gate is the location of one of Kawase Hasui's most famous wood block prints and is worth a photo. My favorite shop for contemporary Japanese Prints, "The Tolman Collection" is located a block east and down the alley with Yoshinoya on the corner just to the east of Daimon Gate leading from the train station to the main gate of the temple.One of the world's tackiest gift shops should you be interested is located on the fourth floor. If you want to do something out of the ordinary you can walk down from the top view level to the 3rd or 4th floor, note this is a clear, non-rainy day as the stairs are out in the open. Takes a while but since you are going down it is not particularly strenuous and you are pretty much alone.I do not remember the fee to go up to the top deck but it is fairly reasonable. My time estimate includes walking from the station, and descending on the stairs.

Great View on a clear day. Of course it's tacky, but what's not to love about a red and white Eiffel Tower? We only went to the main observation deck as the wait and queue for the very top deck was massive. Great views of Tokyo on a clear day, which we were blessed with. Don't get your souvenirs in the crowded shop up there, you can get them on the ground floor. There is also a great food court if you're hungry after having your head in the clouds.

Good view to orient yourself in the city. Bit of a tourist trap but still worth a visit. Watch out for reflections in the windows when you're taking pictures. There are a few spots where you can look down through clear Perspex to the ground below.

More great views of the city. We arrived at the Tower before the rush, on a beautiful, clear day and were rewarded by great views of the city. Fun to see the Mori Tower, from where I had espied the Tokyo tower a few days previously. Clean loos at the top too!
Don't waste your time. This place looks like a cheap mattel version of Eiffel tower. Nothing but tourist trap. So spend as little time as possible and move to next attaction in your list

Tokyo Effiel Tower. To dear all of TripAdvisor, this is my best adventure in the world. The tower tall as 1/4 of Bitexco tower at Vietnam. With more that 120 engine to help it stand still, this thing is unbreakable. With a view of all of Tokyo, this thing is taller that Rainbow bridge at Tokyo a thousand times. This is certainly is Japan architecture. It been a great adventure.

Good view and less crowding than Skytree. It doesn't get the highest view as the Skytree but it much less crowding than Skytree. You can see Mt. Fuji from the tower if the weather is clear. My only complaint about this tower is that they use the shade cover on window that make it difficult to take pictures with DSLR because it will make the sky color blurred.

Mount Fuji seen on a clear Spring morning. Pretty staff in cute uniforms greeted us and send us up to the observation deck. You get a 360degrees view of Tokyo. We saw Mt Fuji with its snow capped tip faraway...but yes it can be seen. There are souvenier shops and a cafe. It is nicely painted in red and was completed in 1958 ...the year I was born.

Loved the view at night. We had a free evening and this tower can be seen from far away. So it made sense to go up it. The view from up top is amazing and it lets you see just how big Tokyo truly is. Views, Views, Views! Must see!

Best seen at Night. Best to see the Tower and Tokyo cityscape at night, from where you get a sense of how big the city is. Only a short walk from the rail/metro and you cant miss it as its easy to see.There is a good view from the first observation deck with interactive screens to point out Tokyo Landmarks. The second deck is worth the extra fee but it can get busy and limited time allowed.If the coach park outside is full you can expect the Tower to be crowded. Typically efficient with lift operators bowing as the doors close and everything clean and well organised. Gift shop on the way down with some unusually strange gift interpretations.

Great idea as a first attraction in Tokyo!. We had to kill some time before we could check into our hotel on or first day in Tokyo so we went to the Tokyo tower. There is two levels and I wouldn't suggest going to this attraction if it is a windy day as the top one closes. But the lower level was really fun! We spent a fair bit of time at each step around the 360 view, and ended up using some of the sights to get our bearings later in the trip! We loved going up the tower!
Worth a Visit. Great view, you can't imagine the size of this city, you can even see the mountains in the distance, glad we went up!
Amazing. if you travel to Japan you need to go in here!!This the best one what Japan has. For me Tokyo tower is more beautiful than Tokyo sky tree.You need to see by yourself to feel it :)

amazing view. the tower is in the popular Minato neighbourhood, entry fee is worth the view from the top... I decided to go there just before sunset, so that it has been possible to see Tokyo skyline during dawn and then gradually going into night, with all the bright lights all around..lookdown windows are there for whoever does not suffer from vertigo.. nice bar and souvenir shop at the top as well as at the ground floor

Day or Night always Nice. Been here twice and its always interesting. First time I went to Tokyo Tower on 2004, the Red Tower so amazing. I came in the night and that time is holiday/weekend i think. Lots of people come and I should queuing very long. But its worth enough. In the night, you can only enjoy the city light of Japan.Second time I went here on 2011 after tsunami. Tokyo Tower looking not so bright because they shut down the light they used to shine due to lack of electricity. I came in the next afternoon.. If you come in the afternoon and there is no fog, you can see Mount Fuji. This time I did not need to queuing very long. Maybe because its afternoon.Tips.1. You might find 4D Arcade for 2 people if you go down with stairs2. You do not need to go to Wax Museum in Tokyo Tower because it is not worth.

WOW!. We came to Tokyo Tower at night to see the bright lights of Tokyo. The amazing views that the tower offers is breathtaking. The lights of Tokyo went out as far as the eye could see, it was never ending. We found ourselves waiting in a famous Tokyo line waiting to catch an elevator to the top observation deck, but the wait is well worth it.After seeing the city from almost 250m above you can head downstairs to grab something to eat and browse through the many Japanese souvenirs. If you're a waffle fan like me, do try the waffles that are downstairs in the food court, they were fantastic!
Nice View. I visited this attraction in February, and found it to be fairly quite so had plenty of room in the observation area. Worth the entry fee for the fine views.

Panoromic view of Tokyo. I visited burj khalifa in Dubai,sears tower in Chicago,empire state building and the wtc in new York city. So Tokyo tower was not a big excitement for me. Of course you get a panoramic view of Tokyo.

Oldie but Goldie. We visited Tokyo tower as part of a city tour.From the observation deck you get an idea of how big Tokyo is. It was amazing. There are plenty of points of interest, a glass floor and shops. Try the Tokyo Banana chocolates.. Beautiful. A must see in Tokyo.
Great Views. It's a little bit pricey I think for what you get but the views are really great if you're looking for an arial view of the city.

A little bit of Paris in Japan?. We arrived on Tokyo from Paris, and found that interestingly, we were staying around the corner from Tokyo tower. To look at this tower does not bring the same emotion as the Eiffel Tower, but it is very worthwhile to take the trip up for the views. This was the first time I truly realised just how vast this city is! Spectacular by night!

A must visit in Tokyo. Amazing specially by night, and you can find many shops & restaurants at there with affordable prices.Reaching there is a bit tricky as the nearest subway is actually not that near and you may get lost due to Tokyo's complicated roads design, so I would suggest to use GPS to reach it from nearest Subway, or just hire a cap (approximately 7 USD from nearest subway station)

A little bit of France in Tokyo. Having visited both the Eiffel and Tokyo Towers, I walked away very impressed w Tokyo's version of the iconic Paris landmark.The differences between the two really come down to how they are set in their respective cities. The Tokyo Tower is tightly set amidst a commercial/high-end residential neighborhood, while the Eiffel Tower is set in the Champ de Mars and adjacent to the Seine. Another major difference is the Tower's impact on their host city's skyline. The Eiffel Tower stands above most of the Parisian skyline, while the Tokyo Tower sort of blends into a skyline that's already full of spectacular high-rises.Their similarities are their iconic visual presence, and providing breathtaking views of their respective host cities.All in all, it's a great way to spend 1 or 2 hours on a clear day or night.

Tokyo Tower. Definitely worth the trip up to see the city from all views. I have been to the Eiffel Tower and while this is based on the same design the observation areas are different as is how one travels up. Thankfully it was a clear day and one could see Mt. Fuji off in the distance. The observation area shows what to look for in each direction which was nice. The price to go to the top was also I think cheaper then the Eiffel Tower. Worthy ones time for a visit.

Some wonderful moment for night time observation especially in winter with the illuminations. + Not too crowded like Tokyo sky tree. old fashion but classic place for observation. Night view from Tokyo tower is cool and romantic. Able to see rainbow bridge from here. Another nice dating place by the way.- A bit far from public transportation like train station.
Fun Sightseeing Spot. This was a fun trip with great views...but I do wonder about those strange little creatures out front! hahaDefinitely worth the trip to the top for the sights!

"…It's A Tower.". There's nothing much to add that hasn't already been written. Looks a lot like Eiffel and affords high vantage point of the city. Quite pretty at night when it's lit - again - looking much like the Eiffel. Been a while since I was there, but still worth the price to go up and check it out. Did not go to Skytree, so cannot make a comparison.
Cool sightline...a bit commercialized.. Awesome views...great perspective of the city...cheap..like $6...a bit of a flea market when you enter- vendors selling cheap trinkets.
Great views. Well worth the cost to take in some great photos of Tokyo from way up. Especially fun to stand on the cut out floor which allows you to look straight down.

Great way to see the skyline and grasp the scale of Tokyo. Okay, so there are TWO towers in Tokyo - Tokyo Tower and Tokyo Skytree. Skytree is the taller of the two and is located adjacent to the Asakusa district; it is also a newer structure. Tokyo tower is older, and smaller, but (the big positive, here) is located quite close to the Odaiba/Tokyo Port area. This means you get a different vantage point from each place. I did not go to Skytree, but I really think the trip up the Tokyo Tower was very worthwhile. I went during the evening and it was a great way to see all of the layers of streets, old and new buildings, apartments and skyscrapers. It is really beautiful at night and a great way to mark the evening in Tokyo. I would recommend visitors go up at least one of these towers while in Tokyo because it is pretty much impossible to grasp the expansiveness of the city from the ground (among the buildings).

Daytime visit. Nice views of Tokyo. There are two options, and ticket price depends on: main observation either "special observation", or something like this. The last one is just higher, not much difference.

I don't know such a beautiful tower... I have seen many towers in the world. But obviously, this is the most beautiful tower at night in winter. The colors of lighting illumination are different depending on the season or the date. I recommend the normal red (orange) light in winter. The light in summer is not because the light color is white.

Great views during the day and night. I went to this around 4PM on January 22nd, and stayed until it got dark out, and it was definitely worth it. The views in both daylight and at night are great. You can see a great deal of the city from the top of Tokyo Tower. The views of Sky Tree and Rainbow Bridge at night are awesome as well. While it's not as new, or as tall as Sky Tree, you shouldn't miss Tokyo Tower if you happen to visit Tokyo.

cool views of the city. 8 dollars to get to the lower observation deck. good views of the city. Nice park right next to the tower. Really nice lighting at night. small gift shop to buy trinkets and postcards.

no waiting line. when i was there no waiting line (i was there to 7 years ago, long waiting line) tokyo sky tree offers a lot more. higher and a better view over tokyo. it looks like the eifel tower but only this one is orange and white. if you are short on time, i wouldt recomend this tower, but this tower i worth a visit. i give it 3 stars because i visit this alread (when sky tree was not yet there) i remember liking it better back then. so if you have your doubts, just go!
great view. Amazing view of Tokyo. No standing in line for tickets or elevator to go up. Liked the bar and the staff very friendly in the tower. Would recommend to anyone.

It might not be the tallest but it still has its charm. Despite that Tokyo Tree took over the title of the highest structure in Japan, Tokyo Tower still manage to offer its old charm with its reddish orange colour and view to the surrounding Tokyo neighbourhood.

Eiffel Tower (Orange Version). This is a great landmark of Tokyo inspired by the Eiffel Tower. The place has a retro feeling and it is less crowded since now all tourists are in love with Tokyo Sky Tree. But honestly I enjoy seeing Tokyo Tower right from below much more than from the top. There's not much to do on top of the Tower except the view and a couple of souvenir shops. After 10-15 minutes you already bored. So if you're on a tight budget or the Tower is too crowded, I suggest that you just enjoy the view and snap some photos from below... it's more than enough. - Watch out for Ultraman ;)

Breathtaking. A brilliant view of Tokyo, keep in mind that you have to pay to get on this attraction Twice if you want to go to the tallest observation deck, if my memory serves me correctly its about 600 yen each to go to the 1st platform and then another 500 yen to get to the second, but if if im honest you might as well pay the fee as its a truely breathtaking view and a once in a lifetime experiance. although the skytower replaced Tokyo Tower as the tallest structure in the world, so you might want to take a trip on the underground to visit there aswell, a day pass on the underground for all lines is 1000 yen which is about £8 or $10. happy viewing.
The Highest Point. Awesome observatory with Spectacular views. Great opportunity to get a panoramic view of Tokyo. Wonderful photo opportunity. Nice little cafés to grab a snack.

lookig at tokyo bye night. the tokyo tower is the place were you can see tokyo bye day and night it is near roppongi the center of night life in tokyo were you can find discos and bar open until 4am,ww of tokyo and the province nar tokyoth tokyo tower had a great view

Ok Views But I like the Paris Version Better. The Tokyo Tower is modeled after the Tour Eiffel in Paris. It is easy to get to by metro. The views from the top were ok, although it did cost us $15 per person. I still like the Paris version better.

Only if you're not afraid of heights!. Although I wasn't allowed on the highest portion of Tokyo tower do to the weather conditions, it was still pretty high. The view from there is stunning and if the sky is clear and you are lucky, you may even see all the way to Mount Fuji! Just don't have high expectations as it is basically consists of two rooms with a very nice view. Sure there is a restaurant in there, but still, unless you are in the mood for staying there just for the sake of getting your money's worth in terms of time spent... it would take you about 30 minutes to go up, see everything, take pictures and come back down. Even less. This was my second visit to Tokyo Tower and it was even shorter this time. Shouldn't be missed, but only if you're completely aware of what you will be getting: a view. Nothing more, nothing less.

Very special place. Tokyo Tower has been a source of Pride for Tokyo for decades and is one of the cities most recognizable structures. The Tokyo Sky Tree has recently taken over many of the roles that Tokyo Tower once served but I feel Tokyo Tower has more charm.At the base you will find a convenience store, some restaurants and lots of gift stores as well. I was kind of surprised at the variety of items at the gift shops and bought a lot of unique things from them.The view from Tokyo tower is sensational. On a good day you can see Mount Fuji, Rainbow Bridge, The Tokyo Sky Tree and much much more. I suggest a visit at Sunset or at night if possible.

a historic landmark. even if Mori building in Roppongi is taller, and now the new TV tower is MUCH taller, Tokyo Tower remains a must-see!If only to catch a glimpse of japanese school children and their enthusiasm in visiting :-)
Neat. Came around Christmas. Was very nicely decorated. I did not go to the top but the shopping and building were unique. Recommended as the night view is very nice.

Not a must. Great view of tower at night. We didn't get to the observation deck since we intended to see Tokyo at night for free at Tocho. But we did go to the souvenir shop floor. It's the only place that sold giraffe Tokyo Banana. I suggest you take a bus ride from any of the train station since the walk can be quite challenging especially after a long day.

Under construction. We went after sunset. We did not plan to go up in it, but were hoping to be able to take some nice shots from below. Unfortunately it was under construction so it wasn't lit up all the way. It was disappointing.

Cool view. Actual tower isn't anything special but cool to see the view from the top. Went during the day and you can see pretty far however I've heard the view at night is more spectacular. A little tourist trappy with all the shops they have you walk by on the way back down however still worth checking out.

Great views at night. We went up the tower at night and the views were excellent. The queue to get to the 250m observatory deck was quite long when we visited, and I think the deck was also undergoing some sort of renovation as well... I would recommend visiting the tower and going up to the 250m deck even though it feels slightly pricey. The tower lights up at night and looks amazing from below too!
Good starting point for a Tokyo visit. Liked the marvellous views and to be able to orientate oneself at the start of our visit to Tokyo. Unrestricted views up to the mountains, Mt Fuji etc.

Icon of Tokyo. Actually going up the tower wasn't terribly exciting for me, as the Tower isn't very tall and there are definitely better views of Tokyo from skyscrapers. However, I really recommend visiting the Tower and just taking photos from below, especially when it lights up at night.

Great value for money. Really good value for money. I only visited this Tower because the new one in Tokyo was full but was not disappointed at all. The views of the City are excellent and gives you a great appreciation of the sheer size of Tokyo with a birds eye view.The cost is great value for money and well worth and hour of your schedule.
Another tower. Although this tower was a historic one built during the surge of electronics in Japan, the experience is similar to going on top of any tower in the world overlooking the city.

Worth a visit if you are in Tokyo. Definitely worth a visit if you have some spare time in Tokyo. The view from the main and the special observatories are well worth it. The crowd was manageable. The park next to the tower is also worth strolling through.

Great value, awesome view of. Not a bad price for a tourist attraction.only went 2nd highest from top which sucked as they said it was unavailable to view yet still charged full price to customers... still good though. must go as you can see traditional cemeteries, Mt fuji & get a feel for tokyo. Highly recommend...

Excellent Views. Went up twice, both at day and night to get the most of the views. Sucked that the 250m tower was out of action for inspection that day but still beautiful! Christmas lights and theme from the main deck was lovely too.
Great Views. Can book tickets online and don't have to q up again, can just go and collect tickets. Great views, reasonably priced, I think 16 euro each per adult.

Loved the rad colors!!!. The views to the skyline as well as the colorful trees and falling leaves made my day. It is probably he best place to have a closer view of the entire city, and the lookdown window was a big hit, nice to make a video while feeling you are also falling down

It's not the Empire State Building. This was ok, we didn't make it to the top because it was closed. I'm not sure if I would have paid the additional fee to get up there. I've seen a magnificent sky view in the Empire State Building and The World Trade Center. This place pales in comparison.

Too Crowded. We were on a JTB / Sunrise Tour. The setting is very interesting in that there are gardens on one side of the tower that seem to have a seasonal theme to them. Inside there is the typical Japanese queue system to get onto the elevator to go up top. At the observatory level we found it very crowded. Make sure you go on a windy day, in the sense that it will be less fog/smog and better views. Only on a clear crisp day can you see Mount Fuji. There are lots of expensive shops at the top for food or souvenirs. They have a little glass floor that you can step on.

Symbol of Tokyo. Tokyo-tower is a unique architecture . This is designed by analog generations.You can see this tower in many place,this is very photogenic . When I came back to Tokyo, Tokyo tower always say welcome back to Tokyo.

Must see attraction in Tokyo. The Tokyo Tower is located in the Shiba-koen district of Minato, Tokyo near the Zojo-ji Temple (which contains the mausoleum of the Tokugawa family). It is also about 3 miles south of the Imperial Palace. I went on a Monday morning in early November and it was a clear day so I could see a lot of Tokyo. I went with a guided tour so we did not have to wait long to go up (just had to wait for a different guided tour).This tower opened in 1958 as a broadcasting tower and was the tallest structure in Tokyo at that time. It looks like the Eiffel tower except it is orange (painted to comply with air traffic safety laws). There are two observation platforms. The main platform is at 150 meters (500 feet) and the smaller special platform is at 250 meters (800 feet). I only had time to go to the main platform which was fine. They said you could possibly see Mt Fuji on a clear day but I am not sure how that is possible since you are not that high. The views from this lower platform were still great as you can see in all directions and get a feel for how huge Tokyo is. The cost is 820 yen for the Main platform and an additional 600 yen if you want to go to the Special platform. Compared to other country’s tourist attractions, those prices are very reasonable.The entrance at the base of the tower is called Foot Town. This is a four story building is located directly under the tower and houses museums, restaurants and shops. You can also buy Tokyo Tower souvenirs at a shop on the main platform.Overall I enjoyed my quick trip to the Tower and recommend it. If the entrance line is not too long it does not take much time to visit this attraction. Tokyo Tower is a must see and iconic Tokyo landmark.

Underwhelming and overpriced. Tokyo Tower is a pint sized replica of the Eiffel Tower - it has a nice enough view of Tokyo's vast but nondescript skyline, but has been wholly eclipsed by the more recent Tokyo Skytree, which is listed as the tallest tower in the world. Ultimately it is really the view itself that doesn't deliver, unless you go on a really clear day and can see Mount Fuji. There are the usual gift shops and food kiosks at the base. All in all I would say skip the Tower and walk down to the beautiful and serene Zojoji Temple just a few hundred yards away for a more traditional piece of Tokyo.
