We went only to the lower viewing deck because it was so cloudy and we didn't see much because of the mist covering the city. It was dim inside, and looked so... tired. Maybe it has to do with the fact that its not as popular anymore compared to the very modern Tokyo Skytree.

Always a favorite. This was my fourth or fifth visit over the course of 25 years. This time we visited late afternoon and into the night. We also decided to go to the second platform. You can only purchase tickets for the second platform at a window on the first platform. It’s always crowded, and there is at least an hour’s wait to go from the first platform to the second, so if you wish to go all the way up, plan for extra time and purchase your ticket(s) as soon as you get off of the elevator. This time, when we left we walked from the first platform to the roof of the main building. Some 600 steps in all.

Great View of Tokyo. We enjoyed seeing Tokyo from the Tokyo Tower. The views were great. The elevator ride up and down was a bit uncomfortable as we were packed like sardines. I understand that it's necessary with so many people, but be aware if you value your personal space.
Great view. Provided a great perspective on the city, worth a visit!It was great being able to enjoy a coffee from the cafe up top.

Essence of Tokyo. This is my very 1st trip to Japan and Tokyo in particular. Despite having a newer (and perhaps the 'better') observatory in town - Tokyo Sky Tree - for 1st timers to Tokyo like myself, a visit to Tokyo Tower is still a MUST. 360 degree views aside, there is a old school romanticism about Tokyo Tower, especially when lighted up in the evenings. When walking in from Kamayicho Station (Metro), the lighted up Tokyo Tower is gorgeous. Best time to go is around 4+ (winter season) - in time to catch the transition from sunset to nightfall for viewers and photographers (the golden hour) alike.As I visited on a Wednesday evening, there is the added pleasure of the Club 333 live music stage (1900 hours and 2015 hours performance) - live music and gorgeous night views, the perfect combination!
interesting. nice view of the city at night. what I particularly liked was the replay of the whole day taped from the tower
Worth the time. Not the ultimate highlight of our trip, but the view gave some perspective as to the real size of the city. We enjoyed it.

A great view of the city. Yes, it is very touristy but what a view. There are two different lines here so be careful. One line is to purchase your time specific ticket, the other to actually go up the tower.Pricey, but worth it.

It's old, but still good. Yes, the Sky Tree is soooo much taller or whatever, but I really enjoy Tokyo Tower. I can directly compare it to the tower in Seoul... and tell you this is a million times better. What can compare of going up and looking at all those iconic blinking red lights on the dozens and dozens of steel towers stretching out before you.

Overview. Tokyo is a very big city, with destination neighborhoods in every direction. The Tokyo Tower is a good place to get started on a first trip to Tokyo. You get a perspective on where the neighborhoods are, A view that makes sense of the maps you have studied

Great views. We went there at night after a long walk from Roppongi Hills. Don't attempt that, even though the tower looks very near! It was a mistake on our part, but the views made the walking all worth it. Tokyo is a very interesting city to see from up high because of all the roads and buildings.

Good view of the city. You will be able to see Mount Fuji on a clear day. We went during the week when they just opened up for the day and there were no lines. it gradually started filling up and by then we were ready to leave.

Great views!. I really enjoyed visiting the Tokyo Tower. The price was approximately $17, which I thought was a bit steep. This included viewing both observation decks. Although it's a bit pricey, I recommend getting this ticket. The views are wonderful from the mid platform, but fantastic from the highest platform. Although it was a cloudy day and the sun was very bright, I was able to capture Mt. Fuji was which no easy feat. We went around the holidays and they had wonderful Christmas displays outside the front entrance.

Been up, loved it.. My sister told me Tokyo Tower was missable. It's not -- if you have a special reason to go. I loved Andy Lau and Sammi Cheng's movie, Love on a Diet, so I absolutely had to see it for myself.If you've been up Macau Tower and N Seoul Tower, here's another one for you -- it's much of the same thing. The view is great, although not spectacular if you're not easily impressed by seeing cities at some height.There's a mall at street level, where you can get the usual food and souvenirs. Tickets are sold just outside the main door of the tower. If I recall correctly it was 800 yen to go up the main observation floor.There are two observation floors. If you want to go up all the way, I'm not sure if you can buy the ticket all the way to the top from the ground floor. They definitely sell the second stage ticket at the main observation floor. But buy your second stage ticket before you have a look around the main observation floor, since there is a wait to go up (about 30 minutes, when I was there). So buy ticket, have a look around, get souvenirs, go up second stage is the way to go.Cute souvenirs at the main observation floor. I got stuff that I didn't see at the other shops.Enjoy!

Tokyo Tower. Tokyo Tower is the world’s tallest self-supporting steel tower. It is a very well-known attraction. The Tokyo Tower gives you a beautiful view of Tokyo and the admission fee is not that much. On rare occasions you can also see Mount Fuji!!!Fee for a primary student: 460 yen ( About $5)Fee for an adult: 820 yen ( About $9)

Not quite the eiffel tower. For some reason this attraction in some guidebooks touts this place as the eiffel tower of Japan. Ok it really doesn't look like it even at night. It sort of looks like a radio tower similar to what I see in the US. At any rate despite this its still a good attraction to see. You do get a great view of the city and even with a slightly cloudy view we were in fact able to see Mt. Fuji. It was certainly worth the trip.

worth a visit at night. yu should visit tokyo tower slightly taller than effiel tower. very organised and have to get a photo clicked at the tower . it costs 1000 yen but worth it. also the view is amazing and to go higher level there is a long wait. nothing like paris but worth a visit.

Showing its age. With the advent of the SkyTree, Tokyo Tower really looks like something from the 1950s. It's hard to call a must on the tourist trail anymore -if you ever could. Many other buildings have higher observation viewpoints, better aquariums (much better!) and are in better locations (Tokyo Tower is not close - by Tokyo standards- to any Metro station). I would not be surprised if one day it was removed and the site redeveloped as maintenance of the Eiffel copy must be high.

Dual observation decks, worth the elevator rides!. The views from both the observation decks were stunning; the second observation deck elevator is high!! We couldn't see Mt Fuji but the information panels for each view (directionally) were very helpful. The look down viewpoints were cool as well, if not scary to stand on and look down! We enjoyed the photo booths on the way out...make sure to have some 100 coins!

The centre peice of any visit to Tokyo. I'd been to Tokyo tower before around 15 years ago and had forgotten just what it was like. Essentially it's a tower or transmitter in the very center of Tokyo, which has a visitors forum and offers splendid views of the city during the day and night. I think of both occasions I visited at night, if only for the romance of the city lights it offers. It's very much a focal point of Tokyo as it can be seen from pretty much anywhere in the city if you get enough feet off the ground. It's fallen under the shadow somewhat of the new Sky Tree, but for me the Tokyo Tower has a bit more class about it than that. It steeps of history and despite of it's central location is a fair old trek if you stick to the yamanote line. I would advised accessing it from the number of subways nearby. Anyway, there are two observatories on offer, so you can pay for the lower observatory or pay a little extra and see both. If I'm being honest I didn't really appreciate the difference of the higher observatory, so my recommendation would be to just pay for the lower one as it has all the extra features such as a restaurant and gift shop that the higher one lacks, and the view is pretty much identical. Whether it was worth the entrance fee I'm not sure, but it's certainly one of those iconic places that everyone should experience at some point in their lives

It's easier to visit the tower as part of a city tour. I visited the Tokyo Tower as part of a Tokyo city tour and I think this is probably the easiest way to do it, since everything is worked out for you. I was very impressed with the tower. Having seen the iconic red and white tower so many times posing as the backdrop for CNN Tokyo programming, I felt that I really had to see it in person. The experience was certainly a good one, and I would definintely recommend that you come here when you are visiting Tokyo. Two things stand out: 1. The organized and friendly staff on the ground floor, in the elevators, and on the viewing level, and 2. The actual views (it was clear on the day that I visited, and I could see Mt. Fuji!).
Great View. Great place to see the city. Definitely go to the top and check it all out. Decent food place at the top while you wait. Really nice and clean.
excellent. Go early evening as the night time view is just lights. Tip, look up when you enter the elevator as it has a glass ceiling.

At sunset reveals the beauty of Tokyo. My friends and I went before sunset and it was gorgeous. It was really a scene made for romance...and as the sunset there was a Love-song radio show going on hosted by this japanese samurai actor. I was able to make a request and it was aired live on the show....it was great! I only wish I was there with my special someone.

Beautiful at night time. We visited in the evening and found the night time views of Tokyo city just beautiful. There was no wait to go up to the Tower, and not too many people on the observation deck. Worth a visit whilst in Tokyo.

Beautiful Views. There are beautiful views from this Tower and unlike the Eiffel in Paris, there was very little waiting time to go up the tower. There is a nice place to eat something while soaking up the lovely views of Tokyo.

A great Showa symbol. After living 10+ years in Tokyo, I visited Tokyo Tower for the first time with my 8 year old niece. Tokyo Tower is not as tall as Sky Tree, but my niece liked it better because of the shape. I, as an amateur photographer, also enjoyed taking lots of stylish photos using this showa symbol tower as a background.After Tokyo Tower, we went to Yanaka Ginza in Taito-ku to make our trip "Showa Nostalgic Tour". It was a great day!
A great tower. The tower is very well organized and not crowded at all. Sometimes communications are tricky. But overall, it is really amazing place to visit. I also liked the temple next to it.
It's worth see this amazing tower.. It's worth to see this tower in de night with its golf shines and attractive lightings.i advice to see this place at night

great view of building during night. Tokyo tower is a nice thing to see, especially at night. for a visit, yes, you should go there and take pictures of building from the outside, but to go up, I think you should do it only if you are a lover of height and city view. if you go up, you can see Tokyo city but not the building itself, so I think it has both positive and negative sides. there are two observation decks, main and special, and I only went to main observatory because price is a little expensive (for me). unique thing is that it has several "look down window", where instead of common floor, they use glasses, so you can actually see below until the ground. a little scary for people with acrophobia, but it's actually interesting and I've never seen it before.
Good view but.... It's nice view from there.But as for me, it's better to see Tokyo Tower from other place than actually going up.
Great Views. Even though the new Tokyo Sky Tree tower is know the must see,old is still gold! Th eviews acroos the Tokyo & surrounding areas on a vlaear day are stunning.

Pretty on the outside but save your money for the bigger brother. First of all, this attraction is definitely worth a visit. As you can see from all the pictures, its really pretty, esp at night. However, to pay 1420 yen to go up isn't worth it. Tokyo Metropolitan Governement office offers free observatory. If you're really dying to spend that money, go to Tokyo Skytree instead, imho.
great Tokyo view. Restaurants at first floor tons of shops open late 10 .30 pm gerat view great experience clean ,easy transportation via subway or bus

Magnificant Views best at night. Visiting Tokyo Tower at night was a highlight of my trip. Like every attraction in Japan, if you don't know the layout of the city or the lingo you are at a disadvantage. Tokyo was easier to navigate than I thought it would be and there are stations close by. Remember 500 metres walking in Japan takes a bit of effort, but at least you get fitter. The Tower is a true landmark and the staff are wonderful. Very reasonable prices. A definate must do if in Tokyo
Good place to see Tokyo. I kept good memories of Tokyo Tower. It was a chance to get a great view of Tokyo from the top of the Tower. Moreover I could take some terrific photos.
Old tower. Was part of a day tour, so a bit rushed, but we found it over rated. We were to.d there was a newer , higher tower,but didnt get there, and couldnt see it, so how high can it be ?

anything the French can do . . . .. This was built as an imitation of the Eiffel Tower and to prove that whatever France can do, Japan can do better - and then paint it orange. You get much better views from the top of the TMG building, and the TMG is free.
central photo point. this is near Roppongi so very easy to get to. went at night, superb photo moments, but it gets old fast. A typical sightseing thing, i loved it!

Very cool views. I only paid for the lower deck but the view was great nonetheless. For about $20 you can spend a good hour or two snapping pics. The sun broke through clouds the day I was there which lent for great shots. Definitely worth visiting.

Beautiful at night.. There is a japanese drama called "Tokyo Tower" that revolves a mother and son story. 1 of the most touching dramas I ever watched in my life. Tokyo Tower is famous and most beautiful at night.

Best view of Tokyo. There is 2 viewing platforms. One is about half way, another 3/4. They require separate tickets. Actually, although the first platform looks pretty low from the outside, it offers the best views.The wax museum, is as many commenters already mentioned, pretty bad.

Exciting way to see Tokyo!. Tokyo Tower offers a nice view of Tokyo. If you are there for the first time (and probably won't go back because it's quite a long walk from any subway stations), you should pay for the admission to the top viewing room, which will automatically give you access to the main viewing room. It's less crowded on the higher floor. However, if you are on a budget, the main viewing room is fine, too, as the views (perspectives) that you get from the main viewing room already look very nice, and photogenic (if not too crowded.)The top viewing room made me felt uneasy a bit coz it felt shaky to me (like mini earthquakes). My husband, on the other hand, did not find it shaky at all. Sunsets at Tokyo Tower also looked very peaceful -- highly recommended.

Everyone should go once :). If you're going to Tokyo, you need to go up the tower! Great view from the top, especially at night, some nice souvenir shops too. Entry is average price for Tokyo, but if you're on a tight budget you're probably better going up the Shinjuku government building which is free. But Tokyo Tower is well worth the visit :)

Didn't get to go up but seemed great. We arrived early and received what essentially is a "Fast Pass" like card to come back in 90 minutes to wait in line to buy a ticket. We did that and spent the 90 minutes wandering the shopping center that occupies at least the first 4 floors of the the tower complex. There were some really wonderful stores here in addition to a wide array of restaurants. We returned at the appointed time and moved the ticket line in about 30 minutes, though considering how long it was that was an extraordinary pace. There are lots of exhibits to look at while you're waiting in line and people watching was equally entertaining. Unfortunately by the time we got to the front of the ticket line we learned it would be another two hours before we got up and back down; we had to get to the airport and couldn't afford the time. I imagine it would have been great but even our time looking around the mall and enjoying lunch was worth the trip. We'll try again next time we go to Tokyo.

Nice View of Tokyo but Can be Crowded. We enjoyed the view of Tokyo but found it crowded at the time we visited. Elevators were filled and had to line up. There is more to do than just the view as well. At the base there is the Ripley's Believe it or Not although most of the displays were only in Japanese which is surprising considering the number of tourists from overseas that visit this center.There is also historical information along with models and photos of tower's construction and what Tokyo looked like since the tower began its construction. Very informative.This is a once is enough tourist spot.Visit the official TOKYO TOWER website for detailed information.

Great view of the city. I thought the lower priced view was just as good as the higher price view, so if time and money are limited, you'll have just as good a view with the lower level. You can see Mt. Fuji on clear days!!
Like being in Paris.. Structure similiar to the Eiffle Tower and built in the late 1950's. Great view of the city along with small shops dedicated to the tourist.

used to be THE Tower, now still charismatic despite the taller Tokyo Sky Tree. Tokyo Tower used to be the "ONLY TOWER" in Tokyo. Among a sea of shorter buildings, due to earthquake proof requirements, Tokyo Tower is a stand out despite it's shorter statue compared with other famous towers in the world. Now we have the Tokyo Sky Tree, it is no longer the pre-eminent Tower in Tokyo, however in the true heart of the city Roppongi area, it is still without peers. A must to visit, better at Night and you can ride the elevator to the top of the tower to take in the panorama. Good luck if you want to climb the Tokyo Sky Tree which is so crowded and tickets are hard to come by and more expensive too.

magnificent night view. magnificent night view of the tokyowe didnt expect the tower to be so beautifulas it is only a steel tower anywayhowever, we were amazed the moment we see the towerthe tower was beautifully lit that made us snap every inches of the towerthe lines for the tickets was quite long that took us around 15 minutes to purchasethe services from the ticket counter until the arrangement for the visitors turn to use the lift was so efficient

Great way to get a perspective on Tokyo. Going up Tokyo tower wasnt one of our holiday priorities, however we just happened to be passing it fairly soon after we arrived in the city. There was no queue and the price seemed reasonable, ( just over 800 yen each), so we decided to give it a go!It actually worked out really well getting a birds eye view of the city. Apart from having lovely views and being almost tourist free, it gve us the chance to work out where we'd been and where we were going, which gave us a chance to appreciate just how vast Tokyo really is!Definitely worth a visit.

Very good view. This is a place to go whren in Tokyo,thje view is fantastic and the city is so sprawling.You only need an hour here and make sure it is a clear sunny day,then you may even see the mount fuji.

A must see in Tokyo. I heard that there is a new tower in Tokyo but we went up the Tokyo tower. As many recommended we didn't buy the package but just the basic fare. And that was good enough. I don't think that the additional price is justified to go up few stories higher. What is really cool is the view window to the bottom. You can see down to the street and stand on the window! The weather was not clear so we couldn't see the Mountain Fuji but the view to Tokyo Disneyland and the Rainbow Bridge were fantastic.

An Iconic Tokyo Experience. Although the Tokyo Skytree has been getting all the buzz lately (which is well-deserved IMHO), the Tokyo Tower is such an icon that I really didn't want to miss it (and was glad I didn't). The Eiffel-tower inspired structure is quite a stunner and at night, just beautiful. At more than half off the price of the Skytree the views though not as high are as inspiring. The crowds were there but getting up was a breeze. I only checked out the main observatory - didn't have time to go up to the special observatory which is much higher up. In all, definitely one of my highlights to Tokyo. On a side note, there's a small retail space at the footprint of the tower but otherwise there isn't nothing much else around.

Tokyo's "top of the Rock"!. In Tokyo for three days and had a spare afternoon before our scheduled meetings. Was recommended the Tower as a good way to get bearings and an overview of city. Great 360degree views with leaflet in English explains the sites. Service it's class and courteous as ever in Japan. There are lots of shops/attractions on the lower floors and also the opportunity to stand on a glass floor looking down! It reminded me of the views you get from the Rockefeller Tower in New York and looks up at the new higherSkytower which has just opened across town. This is great for everyone especially families.

Tokyo... It was a very nice feeling when I was on the height of Tokyo Tower.I could see the full view of Tokyo.But unfortunately I couldn't go to the top section since there was some maintenance work was going on...But I like the place .. It was very nice,..
Skyline view. The view was nice. Pointed out lots of sights around the city, but could jot see most of them due to the buildings that are built up around it.

Fabulous views. A must do when you go to Tokyo Japan. We stayed near there in a hotel and walked around it at night with all the lights on it. Took a tour up in it through the day. Awesome place to visit
Tokyo Tower. Not much to see but buildings that surround it. Before our visit, it was regarded as the tallest tower in Japan but was recently replaced by the Skytree. Spacious parking area though.

Excellent Place !!!. I visited this place 3 times, but this time it looks so promising to me, because i visited it in winter, & it illumination in night was so wonderful & eye catching, that less word to explain it, I will recommend to all visitor to visit it in evening & stay there for a night view, in a clear sky you can view Mt. Fuji San also,

Good views of Tokyo-worth a visit. Reasonably priced and you are not hurried at all-take all the time you want. There were no queues when we went at midday and we only went up to the 1st level (150m and cheaper option) which gave us spectacular views all round Tokyo. We were not rushed in any way and there is a snack bar at the top where you can get some drinks and food; also gift shops. You have a couple of look down windows that you can stand on, if/ you are feeling brave. On the ground floor you have other amusements (like aquarium-extra to pay), food hall and Familymart store for takeaway food and drinks. Well worth the visit.

Still Beautiful to Look at from Your Tokyo Hotel Room. I do not necessarily recommend going to Tokyo Tower for a visit- but it is one of the most romantic sites in Tokyo. If you book a hotel room in central Tokyo for a holiday, request a view of Tokyo Tower from your room. It is modeled after the Eiffel Tower- and is beautifully lit up at night. Sometimes they change the color themes- according to holidays and sporting events, etc.A photo taken with Tokyo Tower in the background is a lovely keepsake. Enjoy!

Fun Spot and great views. Tokyo tower offers great, panoramic views of the city. Lots of fun to walk around, look at the sights and people-watch. The "look down" windows are always a hit with kids. Plenty of food options too.

Don't Miss. I've been into Tokyo Tower twice. Once in January 2008, and more recently, in March 2012. First time was a day time view, the second one was a night time view. Definitely amazing views both times. I'd venture to say that early evening might be the best. Day is great for viewing far out and all, and night is okay for seeing lights. More difficult to make a lot more out. Both times were really nice though to see a change in the city.The second time, I went up to the second observation point on the tower (didn't on the first). Higher up, and obviously an additional fee on top of the fee you paid to get to the general observation deck. I imagine for day time the second one is worth it. For night though, I had this weird sensation I felt CLOSER to the ground even though we went higher up in tower. It was obvious we were higher though because we could see the horizon.The second observation deck is much smaller, being up much higher on the ever thinning tower to the top. Not sure if they limit the amount of folks up there, or if there just aren't as many willing to pay the extra fee, but moving around up there wasn't bad. It was a circular area to walk in. And you could feel the swaying of the wind up that high. Bit disorienting at first.The Sky Tree has opened, but I'd HIGHLY recommend visiting this old friend of Tokyo. It's worth the trip and it's fun to visit what has been the face for Tokyo for years. Plus, you get to see a different area of Tokyo from the air.
Nice view of Tokyo. Went to see the tower on a sunrise tour. Good local attraction, and it had nice views of the city. Be sure to look through the glass panels in the floor that view the ground.

Great View of the City. Great View of the City form the top of the tower.
Cool place to go on your first visit to Japan.

Go early evening for some stunning views. my husband and I have been twice - once as part of a tour, and once on our own. During the daytime you get stunning views (on a clear day) and can see Mt Fuji. You may have to fight for space with local school children on trips though. We then returned at early evening (sundown), and went up to the second observation deck (an additioanl fee, take a ticket and wait for your number). This was well worth it - there were less people up on this deck and the views of the twinkling city lights was fab. Bit of a queue to get back down in the lift again, but to be honest this didnt bother us in the slightest. Dotn be tempted to miss this out now the skytree is open!

Tokyo Tower, Tokyo.. I loved it here. I visited the tower after visiting the Senso-Ji shrine at Asaksua. I managed to get some amazing views of the city. I consider myself very lucky to have had the opportunity to visit the Tokyo Tower and would urge others to see it also. I have uploaded some photos so others may see what great views of the city you get.

Look-down window. We went there mid-day. I expected long lines but there no line at all. Straight up.Superb view. And we had fun with the look-down window, a hardened glass window which you can stand on, looking down. If you dare...
Great views. Great views of the city - we visited both levels and were glad that we did. Nice cafe also.

Worth a visit just for a look, especially at night. We'd visited the Tokyo Sky Tree earlier so hadn't intended to also go to the Tokyo Tower, however we had a free evening so took the quick subway ride for a look. It was an amazing sight lit up at night. We didn't actually go up the tower, but explored the souvenir shops on the ground floor (found some good value there) and had a drink in the beer garden style area under the Tower.We are really glad we visited as the Tokyo Tower as it was a really beautiful sight on a warm and clear Tokyo night.

Still a great spot to see the Tokyo Megatropolis. With the introduction of the Skytree, Tokyo Tower is now very quiet. Skytree is very busy.Easy to get to on the Toei Subway (or other rail options) and you can get up to 250m. The only thing higher is the Skytree. We did not have to wait to get up. It is a great view all the way to Mt Fuji on a very clear day.The other things in the tower were very dodgy, so give them a miss. Also the wax museum was so bad it is almost worth a look (I mean really bad).

It's Worth Your Time. Tokyo Tower is definitely touristy, but it's a cool part of Tokyo's landscape and offers some nice views of the city. Summertime can be hit-and-miss as far as the haze is concerned, so if you're visiting during that time of year, keep that in mind. It offers a few "see through" sections of the floor if you're brave enough to look straight down. And if you have children, you might want to consider checking out the on-site aquarium, too.

One week in Tokyo? Maybe. Only a few days? Not really!. If you have 6-7 days to spend in Tokyo, then I'd say go ahead, but if you plan on staying for only a few days, then there are other more interesting attractions to pay a visit to, particularly when you have already seen the (real) Eiffel Tower in Paris. Of course, the Tower is more than just a photo opportunity from outside, but you'd better go up there on a clear sunny day, which is kind of rare to happen during the months of June-July.It is expensive, when you add up the fares for the Main Observatory, the Special Observatory, the Wax Museum, the Trick Art Gallery, etc. It'll all add up considerably. Now, once you get up to the Main Observatory, you might be a little disappointed, not just because of fuzzy sceneries for that's how Tokyo's weather is most of the times, but also there are not really many landmarks to observe from, besides identifying the main parts of town that you have visited by foot, such as on the east is Shinjuku, or on the west is Ginza, up north is Ueno, etc.If you really want to go up high to have a bird eye view of the city, then you might want to go to Roppongi Hills and pay visit to the Mori Tower with its Tokyo City View. At least, after a short while up there on the Observatory of either towers, in Roppongi Hills you can spend the rest of your day to walk around this newly developed part of Tokyo, with its elegant shops and boutiques and nice people, while Tokyo Tower seems a little dated. I'd recommend to my friends to skip Tokyo Tower for Tokyo City View.

Still worth a visit. I really wanted to go up the Skytree but no tickets were available at the time of my visit just after it had opened so I had to make do with the Tower. The queues weren't bad and it costs significantly less than Skytree.

Nice to look at from the outside......Avoid on a cloudy day!. From many places in Tokyo, the Tokyo Tower looks pretty impressive, especially at night when it is lit up! I have an amazing view of the tower from my apartment and I was really excited to visit it. The tower is really easy to find (unsurprisingly!) and without knowing the way, I was able to walk to it from Roppongi station in about 15 minutes. At the bottom of the tower is a really nice outdoor bar area which would be a pleasant rest stop on a nice day. There is also an amazing crepe shop (Marions crepes) that has a great selection of hot and cold, sweet & savoury crepes for reasonable prices (around 400-500 yen depending on the flavour). There are plenty of places to sit down outside at the bottom of the tower to enjoy a drink or a snack. And as usual for Tokyo, there are plenty of vending machines!Just inside the ground floor of the tower is a great little souvenir shop (Tokio 333) where I was able to stock up on lots of yummy Japanese sweet treats to take home as gifts for my friends. Again, these seemed quite reasonable in price and the selection was pretty good.I paid the 820 yen price to go to the main observatory of the tower but did not stretch to any of the additional extras like the aquarium. The view was ok, but it was quite busy and also very cloudy on the day I visited so overall I was quite disappointed and felt that the 820 yen that I had paid was a bit overpriced. I would therefore recommend trying to go on a clear day to get a good view! Alternatively, visit one of the many free viewing platforms in Tokyo! That way you could enjoy a view of Tokyo that included the Tokyo tower!Just outside the tower there is also a nice little garden park area which you might want to have a little explore of as it provided some nice shade against the hot sun!Overall, I'm glad that I visited the tower (if only for the yummy treats i got at the souvenir shop!) but I regret paying the 820 yen to go up it.

Amazing view. You would get the most out of the view from Tokyo Tower if you visit this site right before sunset. The better view of Tokyo is from the restaurant located on top of Sun Shine Building in the Center of Tokyo. The food there is great and the view is even more breath taking than from Tokyo Tower.

Safe and fun way to view the city of Tokyo. For many years I have seen the tower in Japanese television programs and from the train passing through without every actually visiting it. This year my family and I were able to plan a visit and enjoyed it very much. I am sometimes a little apprehensive about heights, but the tower is very well-built (excellent Japanese engineering) and I felt safe and enjoyed the view. The view from the first platform is very good and it costs more to go higher so I would stick with that one. There are many little shops and restaurants and you can pick up some nice souvenirs and eat at a reasonable price. It is a very good place to visit to see the expanse of Tokyo. We went during the day, but the night would also be good (The illumination of the tower is iconic).

Good start to a tour. As the new tower has a three month waiting list, this was the onbly way to see tokyo from on high. Similar to other towers ( Eiffel,etc) but gives you an idea of the density of the population.
More for the view than anything else. Just go for the view at the top and skip the other floors of exhibits or shopping. A mini Eiffel tower look alike :)

You have to go there if you are in the area!. Only the feeling of walking towards this massive steel construction is worth the journey it self. It is a landmark on engineering qualities. I bought a ticket for the 150m platform and went up in the packed elevator with a crowd of japanese people. Even they where in aw of the view. Unfortunally it was a bit cloudy, but nevertheless worth it. Since I went there on my very first day in Tokyo, I was a bit jet lagged..All my balance sences was a bit out of the ordinary so my feeling was that the whole tower was moving a bit... So, avoid going there if you are jetlagged. You will appreciate it more.There is a small giftshop on the 150m level, where you can buy souveneirs. But there are also several stores on the ground floor, so don't waste all your money on the top one.When you decided to go down, they have made a brilliant solution... You can't go all the way down with the elevator, you have to step out on the 4th floor. And there they have a small carneval, they call it themepark I believe.... But the only theme there is "bring me your money". A lot of small attractions for the children, as an American guy said "Oh! this was really tacky!"Nevertheless, take the stairs one level down and you have a food court kind of thing. Loud, very loud noises and Japanese fast food is available.Next level down is some kind of childrens playground with inflatable walls, like an inflatable jumping castle.When you finally got all the way down to the ground floor you can take the opportunity to go on a shop freenzy at the souveneir shops.

Great view from the top. We bought tickets to see the view from 160 m and from 250 m. You must take in bOth views!!At 160 m they also have loook down glass in the floor so you can see all the way down to the ground !! Everything appears so tiny! To go to the 250 m observatory you have to take another elevator for which they will give you a token number and you wait for your turn. But it's not a lOng wait and you can take in the views from the 160 m observatory while you wait for your tOken number to come up on the display screen for the elevator

Nice view of Tokyo. With 2 different viewing platforms you get quite a good view of Tokyo. Reasonably priced and on the day I went there was no line up or crowd - this may be due to the fascination with Tokyo Skytree which has just opened up. There is also a shopping centre at the bottom with souvenir shops, food court and games arcade that would keep kids of most ages interested for a few hours. While Tokyo Tower may be taller than the Eiffel Tower it lacks the beauty and grace of its French counterpart.
Great Views of city. Make sure to go on the clearest day possible. Weekends the lines can get long so be prepared especially in the summer.

Lovely Tower. Tokyo tower has 2 observatory, one at 150m which is what you get when u buy the tickets from the entrance on ground floor then there is the 250m special observatory where u can buy tickets for another 600yen more to enter it. I do not understand why that was the case and the view from 250m was way better than the 150m one. Other then the pricing strategy, this place had one of the best views of Tokyo. Nice! but probably is going to be surpass somewhat by Tokyo Sky Tree but from exterior perspective, tokyo tower looks much nice than sky tree. So still would recommend it as good photo spot and good viewing of the city

Lots of fun, must do with children. I went with my 2 children. At Christmas they have great lights & decoration at the base. The ride up is fun with stops at different levels. Great view of the city when sky is clear, see bridges, bay, Mount Fuji.Great gift shop, play room, bouncy castle ( additional fee).

Great Views of Tokyo. On a clear day like we had, the views from Tokyo Tower are very impressive, its the only way to fully appreciate the size of Tokyo. 360 degree views of the city out of an awesome structure. We went early so managed to avoid geting stuck in the mid-morning rush. If you are planning to go over a weekend get there early it gets really busy.

Perfect complement of the night views from Mori Tower. It's a copy of the Tour Eiffel and it gives the same chance to embrace the city from the top observatory. It is great to understand part of Tokyo urban design.
Great view at the top!. Great views at the top but kinda boring at the same time too. You have to pay to go right to the top, and there's long waits, but the view in the middle is great.

Great views but a bit boring... Don't get me wrong.. The views up there are amazing. You have to pay more to go to the very top.. Is kinda worth it, but still it only took us about an hour in total to go to both levels of the tower and have lunch in the cafe at the bottom. I do think it's something you should check off your list, I'm very glad I did it. But you don't need to spend very Long up there
Beautiful Tower!. Recommend you to visit the tower at night when it glitters.Few minutes from Shiba koen station on Mita-line.Take a walk to Zojoji Temple & Shiba Park located near by.

All about Tokyo Tower and Imperial Palace.... The Tokyo Tower is higher than the Eiffel Tower. It is the best way to view the landmarks of Tokyo. Just make sure that the sky is clear and the weather is fine or else, the scene will be covered with fog or clouds. There are two levels of the tower that you can choose from: either you'd be on the middle part or on the top of the tower. ---Middle costs JPY820 and the Topmost costs JPY1420. I think the topmost view is great but the middle is fine. You can see the landmarks already and their is a glass floor where you can see the cars below.Imperial Palace is a nice place to stroll around. It has one of the best sceneries of Tokyo especially when there is not too much people and the weather is cool. There are many exits so if you get lost, don't worry too much but it is quite a large park. You can find beautiful trees and cherry blossoms there. Don't miss the moat - where you can see how the palace is separated from the outside through the body of water, for protection during the olden times.No entrance fee.How to get to the TOKYO Tower from SHINJUKU?Ride the TOEI EODO line from Shinjuku Station to DAIMON (LINE 20). After reaching the station, read direction on how to go to TOKYO TOWER exit. You can see the tower as soon as you go out the station, it is around 7-10-min walk. Souvenir shops are abundant. Ticket to the tower are bought outside, you can ask the friendly Japanese staffs.From Tokyo Tower to Imperial Palace:From Akabaneshi or Daimon station ride to AOYAMA-ITCHOME (E24) transfer to the purple or HANZOMON LINE and go to Hanzomon station (Z05). Imperial palace is in OTEMACHI.

Great views from the top. We visited the tower as part of a full day tour with Tokyo Tours. The views were pretty spectacular and had good english descriptions of the buildings around the tower. There was a glass window on the floor which my wife and daughter enjoyed standing on. There was the usual gift shop, but you never felt pressured into buying anything.It is reasonably priced and will use up 40mins to 1 hour.
Awesome views, great attractions. Not just a tower but a collection of attractions too. Was raining when we went (Aug 2008) so couldn't see very far but was a good trip none the less.

Nice Views. The new Tokyo Tower wasn't open yet when I was there, so I settled for the original tower. I don't think it looks anything like the Eiffel Tower, nor is it as tall. But you still get very good views of Tokyo and its skyline. If you like taking good pictures, you can get some great ones at dusk. But once the sun goes down, the view doesn't look as impressive and there's light glare off the windows. On Friday nights, there's a small live band that plays music at the cafe on the observation deck which is pretty cool. There are 2 observation decks: a lower one, and a higher one. You have to buy a ticket to get up to the first one, and then you have to buy another ticket when you get up there if you want to go to the second deck. There was like an hour wait to get up to the second deck, plus it was about the same price as to get up to the first deck, so I didn't think it was worth it.

Great Views at Night. A short walk away from Hamamatsucho JR station. In fact it is the closest station for the Tokyo Tower. If you enjoy a long walk, it can be done brom Roppongi.I visited the Tower both during the Day and the Night. Great views during both times although I prefered the night. The entry ticket wasnt that expensive, cannot remember the exact prices but they were under $15 AUD for an adult. Refer linked website.It is one of those touristy locations, so you will run into alot of tourists.Great location for families with kids to visit.If your buying souveniers, its advisable to buy them at the lower floor. The prices are a bit cheaper and there are way more shops and items to choose from.

Beautiful views of Tokyo. It's well worth the trip to the tower. I went on a clear day and the 360 views were amazing. It was $8 US to get to the 150 meter platform and from there another $6 US to get to the 250 meter observation deck. The views from 250 meter are much better.

Amazing views with some drawbacks. Tokyo Tower is a must! The 360 views are unbeatable and the additional cost for the higher observation deck was defiantly worth it. Slight drawbacks include a headache from the quick elevator ride up and a very crowded upper deck with a long line to catch an elevator back down. If you have any trouble with being in close quarters with lots of people you probably shouldn't be in Tokyo anyway, but you certainly should not be on that observation deck!
Great shots at Twilight. I did not visit the tower but took some great twilight shots of the tower!

A great way to see the skyline. One of the most distinctive features of the skyline, Tokyo Tower was built in the 1950s in an area that looked to be working class people. It's main function is, of course, radio and television communication. However it also features to observation decks. One at 150 meters the other at 250 meters.There is a charge to go to the observation decks but it is well worth it. We went on a moderately clear day and had an excellent view of the city and surrounding metropolises. The staff is friendly and helpful. We went during that regions school vacation week and even though it was crowded - the wait was not too long.

Lovely views, but a little crowded. This is worth a visit if you are not sure what else to do.Very quick to queue and get to the top and the views are quite nice, especially at night, but be prepared to share it with A LOT of other people.There is a nice restaurant at the top, which is very romantic, but like most it is also very expensive!If you're looking for something to do on a rainy afternoon then i would recommend this place

Visit by Night for a spectacular view. I visited around 7 o'clock in the evening, no queues straight in to the lift. There is evening entertainment in the lower observation deck which was very good. Tokyo really looks impressive when all lit up in the evening.

Kitschy but a good view. This place has a very cheesy, tourist-trap vibe to it, but the view from the the decks at 150m and 250m is great and will help you get oriented in Tokyo.Unless you've got kids, I would skip all the stuff in the base floors, and focus on the views.

Amazing views of an amazing city. Although one of my guidebooks classified this sight as "overrated," I'm glad I went to check it out for myself. It is designed like the Eiffel Tower, but is a vibrant red that can be seen from many spots in the city. There's a temple near the tower that is also worth a visit. The tower is very clean and efficiently run, staff are very friendly, and there's many shops and food outlets in the tower. There's a small restaurant and bar on the lower observation deck. There are two observation decks and a charge to visit both (you pay an additional charge to the regular ticket to get to the higher deck). I don't remember the exact price, but it was not outrageously expensive (although if you have a large family, it may get cost-prohibitive to go to the top deck). Even though we went on a slightly overcast day, the 360 degree views of Tokyo were fantastic. On clear days, they say you can see Mt. Fuji, although we did not. We watched the sunset from the lower observation deck and it was a wonderful experience. The elevators are very fast and smooth, so you feel safe if that's a concern. Although with the Tokyo SkyTree opening in May, I'm not sure if Tokyo Tower will have quite the pull it does now, but it's still a fun place to visit and it has a very cute gift shop (if you're into that sort of thing).

Nice couple of hours apart from the aquarium.. I stayed in Roppongi for a couple of nights and went to the tower for a few hours. I didnt go up the tower as you can get the same kind of views from most of the hotels but If you arent in a high floor I would imagine the views would be amazing.The tower has lots of small stalls near the base that are cheap compaired to the shops so great place to pick up gifts for people back home.I did visit the aqaurium which I would tell everyone to avoid at all costs. The cost to the attraction is as much as Osakas (one of the biggest in the country) and it really is a horror show inside. I have kept many marine fish for years and was shocked at the conditions the animals are kept it. As many fish as possible jammed into tiny tanks. 3 foot fish put into a 2.5 foot tank. Certain fish that are known to be shy and need hiding spaces kept in bare glass tanks and the stories go on. This place really should be closed down or reduced in size and the exiting tanks increased.PLEASE AVOID THIS PLACE AT ALL COSTS !!!!!!!!I didnt think it was the easiest place to visit as didnt seem to be that near any subway stations but I may be wrongs.
Awesome night lights. it was easy to find. The night view was amazing. However, the highest level was close for maintanence. Still the night view is worth it.

Nice view, good to experience a piece of history. But in the end it is just a tower. If you are pressed for time, you should probably just go and take photos of the outside of the tower from the base, rather than going all the way up. There isnt much to do here other than going up to the tower and then down again. To make matters worse, you have to pay double the price to go all the way up. Though the view is nice, I felt a little ripped off. I ended up valuing the photos I took of the outside of the tower more than the ones I took on the inside. For pricing:http://www.tokyotower.co.jp/english/05_info/index.html
After Eiffel tower this is most facinating. You can see Tokyo on a clear sunny day. Lovely structure. I wish to go there again........Daimon is the nice place to visit before you go up this tower.

Pretty from the outside. I visited Tokyo Tower through Hatobus tour, which covers the entrance fee to the main observation deck. The panaramic view of Tokyo from the top of all of Tokyo was aweinspiring, but it's comparable to the view you get (for free) from the Tokyo metropolitan government buildings in Shinjuku. I think the tower itself is striking from the outside with its red color, and is good for a photo op with the tower in the background. One thing I didn't get to experience much -- there are some souvenier shops on the first few levels of the tower which would have been interesting to explore. Be sure you have enough time to do that, especially if you tour through Hatobus which makes a 45 minute stop at Tokyo Tower.

Incredible Views. I only had one day to visit Tokyo so I decided to take a tour that included Tokyo Tower. The views of Tokyo were incredible, and we were lucky enough to visit on a day when Mount Fuji was visible. I enjoyed the elevator ride to the observation level and looking down through the clear floor panels.If you have time, you can grab a cup of coffee or a drink at the cafe in the tower and enjoy the surrounding view.
Great Views - spectacular. An amazing experience. We could see Mt Fuji in the distance. Wonderful views of the whole city. Do it - go right to the top.

The Special Observatory 250m is shut until 29 Feb!. We went along to the Tower on Wed 15 Feb, only to find that we could only get to the first level - the Main Observatory 150m (820 yen). T'he main reason you would go is for the Special Observatory 250m (for an extra 600 yen), but they have closed the elevator for maintenance. No mention of it at all on their website, so be warned if you were hoping to go all the way to the top over the next couple of weeks!

Still stunning. Soon to be outshone, in terms of vertical height, anyway, by Tokyo Sky Tree, Tokyo Tower remains a stunning attraction -- both to look at and to look out from.The tower is at its most beautiful lit up at night, as it's bright orange girders seem to be on fire. As with most such attractions, the main attraction is the view, and the view is best enjoyed during the evening transition from day to night. And its rival, the Tokyo Sky Tree, will never be able to invoke the ghosts of Godzilla the way Tokyo Tower does. You can just imagine the big guy crushing it with his huge foot in those cheesy movies of the 1950s.Like most Japanese tourist draws, the available food is pretty bleak, so plan to eat before or after your visit. You might have to wait up to an hour on weekends and holidays, but you should be able to go up, at least to the mid-height viewing level, much more quickly on a weekday.
View. 'View' is the only word that's needed. Doesn't offer anything else and doesn't need to. Best views of Tokyo for my money.

fantastic view. It's one of the tallest buildings in Japan and is painted bright orange. That alone is enough reason to see it. The view is beautiful and you can even see Mount Fuji in the distance. Hubby and I loved it, definitely a must see if you're in Tokyo. The gift shop is pretty affordable too and has a lot of variety. Good place to buy souvenirs for the family.

Romantic place. my impression to this place is beautiful and romantic. You can see the beauty of Tokyo and they have interactive monitor who can give map from the past until now. The height is 332 m and it's higher that Eiffel Tower. They have wax museum inside but not really amazing.

GO AT SUNSET. I went at sunset on a day with alright visibility and it was stunning. I was able to get amazing pictures of the sun setting over Mt. Fuji.The best part of going at this time is you get to see the city during the day with just a few lights on then after the sun sets you can see the city come alive! I still don't know if it's worth going to the top. I have been to 150m and 250m and both were fine.

Must see if in town. It's the Eiffel Tower of the East, you can't miss it! We had a great view of the tower from our hotel room (the Grand Arc Hanzomon, see my review for that) and knew we had to venture out to find it. It took us two trains, but we finally arrived and were able to find it relatively easy just by walking in the right direction. There are plenty of gift shops and eateries on the ground level of the tower, and during Christmas time there was a cute Christmas light display around the base that you could access for free. There was also a mini beer garden outdoors (mostly just a few picnic tables and a few booths selling drinks). We paid our admission and took the elevator up to the top. It was not too crowded and the views were worth the price of admission though we didn't stay long (we went at night, I imagine both the daytime and nighttime visits have their own appeal). We actually made it up to the tower of every large city we visited in Japan, and this was a fun little theme to go with.

Tokyo tower on a rainy evening. It was fabulous watching the night lights come on and the traffic increase on the roads above us. The computer aided views were great, but not available for every view. Not all of the information (such as height of buildings) was availble. We stayed for 90 minutes though, and thoroughly enjoyed it. Easy to get to from central Tokyo/Ginza station, getting off at Kamiyacho station on the Hibiya line, it is well signposted from the station.

Tokyo tower..Used to stay and overlook the same. Reminds me of the other tower in Paris :-) The bigger one, but the Tokyo tower is more nice and smaller and more compact. Plus i love the lightning of the same. Overall great place to go and visit...

Magical view of the city of Tokyo. The view is breath-taking. We were amazed to see how beautiful the city is with the mixture of modern and traditional architectures, both big and small. If you like to take pictures, go here on your own instead of taking a tour group because most of them hurries people up, not giving enough time to take pictures while at the observatory and at the foot of the tower. We were only able to take a picture while we were on the observatory, they can be found here: http://www.travelingyoungcouple.com/2011/10/japan-odaiba-tokyo-tower-and-asakusa.html

Great view even in the rain. For the upcoming young adults, the Tokyo Tower is a symbol of Tokyo much like Godzilla is to Japan. It was one of my must see's when I went to Tokyo, and I was not disappointed. There are two fees you can pay, one for the main observatory at 150m, and the the other for the Special deck at 250m.The day I went it was raining so I chose the main observatory. This section has two floors to view from with a cafe on the top floor and a small gift shop on bottom. You will take an elevator to get to the observation deck, but you have to use stares to walk between the two. The cafe wasn't open so I can't was anything about the food, but I went to the gift shop and found it was reasonably priced. The view from this deck is awesome and a great way to see Tokyo. On a clear day you can see Mt. Fuji, but on a raining day you can only see a few miles out. None the less it's still worth doing.Once you leave the observation deck you'll go to the Foot Tower which is the 4-story complex below. It has lots of little shops, things to see, a McDonald's, a Hello Kitty Shop, and bathrooms (Watch Out! Some of the toilets are the "hole in the ground" versions).Be sure to bring a camera/video camera for the great view, some comfy shoes, and around $9 (820yen) per Adult, $5 (460yen) per child. You can easily spend 2 hours in the observatory and a few more in Foot Tower. You can reach it by using the subway and a short walk, or taxi.

View Tokyo from what was once the tallest free-standing tower in the world. Tokyo Tower is a nice place to start a tour of Tokyo. Once, the tallest free standing structure in the world at around 333 meters, it was built in 1958 to broadcast TV and radio signals. Now, the tower is eclipsed by many skyscrapers in Tokyo. Be aware; there are two fees: one to gain access to the main observation deck around 150 meters up and another to access the special observation deck around 250 meters up. A new tower, Tokyo Sky Tree (around 632 meters tall), is nearing completion in 2012. But Tokyo Tower is impressive, nonetheless and an icon of Japan worth visiting.

out of this world view on new year's eve!. i went to tokyo tower on new year's eve, 2010 and it was AMAZING! there were so many different types of people there, which was nice to see having been an American studying abroad in Japan at the time. It was incredibly crowded and there were lots of drunk people, but it provided for a festive environment. in the tower itself, we saw all of tokyo at night on new year's eve. it was absolutely breathtaking, and i still remember how amazing i felt when i was up there with people from all over the world on one of the most important days of the year. what was best about this experience is - i left my camera in the restroom and thought i lost it, but someone returned it! i was so happy since it was a very expensive camera that i received as a gift from a family member. god, i love japan. all i can recommend is that ladies - make sure you have a phone on you and are with someone, because with how many people there are, you may get felt up/coerced into going somewhere with someone you don't want to.

Wait for the lift or conquer your fear of heights walking down the stairs.. Tokyo tower provides a panoramic view of the Tokyo skylines. When I was there I was fortunate/unfortunate to see a trained monkey doing tricks out of the front of Tokyo tower. Yeah it was something different.
Tokyo tower is a great piece of Architecture, and worth the trip to the viewing area.

Beautiful view, worth coming once at least. Went on 16 Dec 11. This was never on our itinerary but as we walked down Roppongi, we saw the tower and just followed the lights. Upon arriving, we realised that the admission fee was tiered such that you had to pay twice to go all the way up. Main observatory was ¥820 and Special Observatory was ¥600 more. Unless you want to be able to boast that you've been all the way up there, the main observatory should suffice as you can get nice 360 shots of the area. At every segment around the main observatory, there is a touch screen where you can check out the time lapse view of that segment from day to night. That was really interesting and you will at least get to see how the view is like throughout the day, meaning if you came in the day, you will have a feel of how it looks at night and vice versa. There's also a couple of "look down windows" which are essentially holes in the floor but with covered with glass panels to prevent you from falling down. It's a little scary looking down at that height but pretty interesting. Overall worth going at least once.

You could see the great view of Tokyo. I have to say we really enjoyed Tokyo Japan such a modern city and the people so nice. The Tokyo Tower was amazing you could see the whole city from the top of the Tower.This was my 3rd trip to Japan I could not get over how clean everything was. I can't wait to return.Karine and Jeff.

Go for it!. Not that I find Tokyo an amazing city, but being an architecture fan, I find it imperative to see as many buildings of such a huge city as possible.The Japanese architecture doesn’t attract me that much, but I like to see how the city was planned and how it evolved. You can see the various districts from the Tokyo Tower and it actually offers a very decent panorama of the city.I went a little bit before the sunset expecting to get some nice colours on the city, but as it was December and as there was a lot of smog around, the light wasn’t at its best. Nevertheless, I managed to get a good glimpse of Fuji-san and from pretty much all Tokyo.Please be advised that the queues can be cumbersome, especially if you want to go to the upper deck – at my time of visit, at least 60 min waiting time. I didn't go to the upper deck, but I was already satisfied with the normal deck.To come down, I recommend that you take the stairs as they make up for good exercise and you can see other details from the city. I believe that the ticket was 1300 Yen, so that makes 13€, which is an ok price for an expensive city as Tokyo.In summary, do it for a good view of the city and be sure to go some time before the sunset so that you still get a nice light. Then come down when it’s already dark, and you'll be surprised by the beauty of the light that decorates the Tokyo Tower.

(Almost) Bird's Eye view of Tokyo. A landmark attraction when visitng Tokyo. The tower viewing platform allow visitors a (almost) bird's view of the Tokyo. My wife and I visited the tower during the afternoon hence we have a clear view of Tokyo city. I believed the scenery would also be great during nighttime. If possible, visit the tower on your own so that you can take your time to enjoy the sceneries. The visit was a bit rush for my wife and myself as we sign up for local tour and tour guide keep reminding the group that we cannot spend too much time there and has to move on to the next attraction.

Very colourful,. Movement of visitors and tourists was well organised by staff. Very good views from tower at night, Christmas lights on trees at ground level quite spectacular, plenty of opportunity for personal pictures in front of exhibits etc. Found everybody to be very friendly, happy and safe environment.

Tokyo Tower – See Tokyo 360. Visiting any high object with a view of the city you are in, gives you an easy overview of the layout. We fine-tuned our route for later in the day due to what we observed.We had planned on taking the stairs but this is only possible in the weekends (it is free and you supposedly get a certificate).There are two levels to the Tower and you pay extra for the upper portion (bring cash credit cards are not taken). We thought it was well worth the extra fee because you get a different perspective of the city. I asked one of the guides which main street I was looking at. To my surprise (even after asking her supervisor and getting out a book of maps) I never got an answer. Take a video of the elevator going up. You can see the tower and sights beyond. There are windows situated in the floor which is a nice touch. Also be sure to pinpoint a spot and watch the sway of the tower.I can’t say anything about the restaurants there but the gift store was a disappointment.There are other ways of obtaining views of Tokyo, some free and some not. Be aware that restaurants with a view apply a hefty cover charge. Night views looking towards Tokyo Tower are a must!

Average experience. Since its more famous - you got to visit this..however i still feel, i had nice experience in government's building in Shinjuku (45th floor observatory) -and its free.tokyo tower is more commercial. Good to see once!!

Excellent view of the entire city. Being a most-often business traveler, there is a lot less that I get to see @ places I visit. But Tokyo tower enabled me to just get in a jiffy what the entire city stands for...the amazing breathtaking view of the city helped me understand how far ahead the city is regards the rest of the world...yet has a tradition and heritage. I took numerous pictures of the different spots seen from the location. Also, a night trip to the tower was mesmerising. Wax museum is an added attraction at the tower.

Great views of Tokyo city.. Tokyo Tower is worth a visit when in this amazing city. Arriving at the tower there is plenty to see and do and always something going on. We were entertained by a monkey doing tricks and the crowd enjoyed it. The tower itself allows access to the main observatory, a quick ride in the lift and you can see outside going up the tower. At the observatory level (333meters) you get 360 degree panoramic views of Tokyo city. On this floor level is the souvenir shop, cafe, rental scopes, lookdown windows. On a clear day you even see Mt Fuji. The day I was there I couldn't see it. Great views and signs indicating different areas of the Tokyo region and how far away they are. There is also a level down with restrooms. Taking the lift back down, it stops on level three taking you out into Carnival town, a ride and play area for kids, take the lift again to the second floor where there is a huge range of souvenir shops ( I noticed somewhat cheaper than buying at the observatory souvenir shop) food outlets including McDonalds and other stores with plenty to see.The ground floor at the entry to the lifts for the tower isthe Aquarium Gallery, Tower gallery 3-3-3, Tokyo Tower wax Museum, Noppons Magical Dungeon and Space Wax.The main observatory is open from 9am until 10pm year round. Tickets 820yen adults. Kids from 4 years of age 310yen.Prices for other TT attractions: Noppons Magical Dungeon 500yen adult Kids 400yen.Wax Museum: 500yen adults, kids 350yen.Space Wax: Adults 500yen kids 350yen. The Aquarium Gallery is free.Interesting place to see and visit and generally something for everyone.
The Tower. Fantastic views of the city. Restaurant at the top with a few small shops where we found some cute little presents for the family.
Fantastic views of Tokyo. Amazing 360 degree views of Tokyo, so makes it a perfect place to try & appreciate the sheer size of Tokyo

A good view of Tokyo. We bought the special ticket that allowed us to go up to two decks, the regular one and another that's 200m higher. One deck was really enough as the taller deck gave us the same view. There wasn't much of a difference except the taller deck was a lot smaller.There isn't really much to do at the tower, but see a 360 view of the city. Regardless, it's still a tourist must-see area.

Do not accept any credit card.. It's pretty! I love Tokyo Tower but I find it interesting that they do not accept any credit card at the admission. It is a world famous tourism spot. Its hard to believe it.....

Nostalgic tower.... Tokyo's landmark TOKYO TOWER will become the 2nd tallest tower in Tokyo early next year. However, you will be excited when you reach the firstobservatory deck!!! square size clear panels on the each sidecan see through onto the ground.(extra fee apply to the 2nd deck. )Easy walk from Hamamatsu-cho stn. just pass Zojyo-jitemple(must see!) There is a food court on the 3rd floor,Mcdonald's, Japanese food, snacks etc. also free enrtyto a historical museum run by NHK broadcast.
Nice. Nice to see the city from Tokyo Tower. There is floor of transparent glass from where anybody can see the things under his feet.

Good First Impression. This was the first stop on the Group Tour that I was with, and originally just a photo opportunity before proceeding to the next destination on the itinerary. However, there was sufficient interest within the Group for a trip to the main observation deck, so up we went. Thought the views from the tower were pretty impressive, dispite the cloudy weather, and I ended up being glad that we did decide to take the time out of our full schedule for it.Yes, I'll have to admit it was a bit cheezy overall in a touristy fun sort of way (especially some of the food gifts in the ground floor gift shops). Normally, I would give this an overall Average rating, but since the views made a good first impression of Tokyo on me (and being a long time fan of Japanese monster movies), I bumped it up one notch. Not sure if I'll make a second trip here on any future visit, since Tokyo Sky Tree should be in operation by then (and there is also Tokyo City View at the Mori Tower in Roppongi Hills to consider).
Awesome. Make sure you go to the highest level. There is a fee however it is well worth it. Very nice sushi restaurant on top.

Eiffel tower copy with a great panoramic view of Tokyo. At 333 m an impressive structure. Inspired by the Eiffel tower (320 m). Main observation deck at 150 m and a special observation deck at 250. The panoramic view is awesome. I got great photos due to the great weather. It's a bit costly, but I think it is worth the visit. The kids liked it.

Photographers Delight - Night Time Viewing a Must.. I visited this relatively modern site in Tokyo to get a great night view of the City at it's best for taking photographs. I spent over an hour walking around the main viewing deck. I took over 200 photos with the aim of producing a 360 view and some panaramas. It took that long due to the number of people standing at each of the interactive information stations telling you what buildings & other attractions were out there lit up at night. The rest of the tower such as resurant if you booked in advance was a great place to sit & eat a romantic dinner for two with literally the world at your feet.

Cheesy Tourist Fun!. We were staying in Tokyo for a week and we took advantage of our Metro day passes by jumping on and off the trains checking out all the tourist attractions. The Tower is just around the block from the Kamiyacho station on the Hibiya line (follow the many maps and signs - you can't see it from the station exit or anything, but it's just around the corner). We arrived on the regular observation floor right about sundown, it was beautiful to watch Tokyo light up! You ride an elevator up and there are other attractions (for additional fees) and shops inside as you work your way back down. We had fun in the haunted house/movie and checked out a few shops but were getting hungry for dinner, so we moved on...it was cool to look back at the Tower from Roppongi Hills (our next stop).....this was our second trip to Tokyo, but our first to the Tower....I agree with previous reviews in recommending the Government Building in Shinjuku as a great view for free - but I do think the Tower is worth a visit if you're in that part of the city or have some time to burn! I would've liked to check out the Zojoji Temple, you can see it just below the Tower from the windows, but it was dark and we were tired from hiking Mt Fuji the day before and didn't want to do the extra walking.

Just another tower but beautiful views.. The Tokyo tower was part of our full day Tokyo tour which I recommend if you are short of time while visiting Tokyo. It is just like another tower ( the CN tower and eifel tower most comes to Mind) it features a viewing deck and of corse some glass viewing areas. There are plenty of over priced souvenir shops and some cages and restaurants in the ground floor. There is even a m donalds there :). The views are spectacular on a clear sat. You may even be able to see mt Fiji. There are shogun temples nestled in between highrise buildings and the river. A definate must see if you are in Tokyo. ( until they finish the new Tokyo tower which will be taller than This one this is still under construction)

Great attraction, but a bit costly. Great attraction, value for money for the first segment and nice view. No point going to the top as the view will be similar. Must try to order some drink at the cafe and relax - enjoy the great scenery. My advise - try to go in the evening as the City view will be better.

Skip it! Much better things to see in Tokyo. Sorry....a mini version of the eiffel tower that isn't nearly as tall or beautiful and is super cheesy and ugly on the inside??? Skip it!! There is an "aquarium" which is a couple of fishtanks" and a McDonalds inside. Granted, the view might be nice but so is the view at the Park Hyatt or a number of other places in town. Please don't waste your valuable Tokyo time!
Classic but outdated. Views are not so great as in e.g. Mori Tower and bit pricy.

Yeah, no.. Honestly, Tokyo is not the most attractive cityscape on the planet. So, seeing it from on high is not that spectacular. Added to that are the cost, crowds, waiting times and you are left with a fairly forgettable experience. The street sign pointing the way as you approach says 'Tokyo Towershita'. Could not have said it better myself.

Worth the visit - beautiful view of Tokyo!. Worth the payment to go to the first level of the tower. High enough to see Mt. Fugi and a 360 degree view of Tokyo. The special observatory level was not worth the extra cost. You could see everything you wanted on the main observatory level. Save the money needed for the second level and buy a souvenir!

The best Eiffel Tower copy you will ever see. This tower is better than the Eiffel Tower - from the technical side: lighter, higher, stiffer, more modern at all. The view from the top is magnificent (if you have a nice day or night) and I recommend to stay for a sunset since you will see an ocean of buildings turning into an ocean of lights. The entrance fee is kind of expensive but "normal" for Japan. Unfortunately, it needs quite a long walk to get there when arriving by metro.

Expensive but worth a visit if you have extra cash. Standing tall in the middle of the city, you'll have a great 360 degree view. We were lucky enough to have a clear day, so we got to see Mount Fuji and the Rainbow Bridge. However, it's not worth the amount of money and the lineups. If you're planning to go, make sure you make the most of it. They have a great cafe that you can do some people watching and a great playground for kids to enjoy.With all honesty, you can get a better value if you go to the restaurant at the top of Grand Prince Akasaka Hotel, where you'll have a great food while enjoying a fantastic view of the city.

Skip It. Not accessible for handicapped individuals.. Tokyo Tower does give you a nice view of the city but remember #1) it is full of school groups during daytime hours, even on Saturday; #2) You will not get a view of Mt. Fuji. This region of Japan is often hazy and cloudy. Clear days are rare and exist primarily during winter months; #3) It is not handicapped friendly as there are areas of the tower only accessible by several flights of stairs. DO NOT get sucked into the 'wax museum'. So bad. I believe it may be where the apprentices send their first drafts. Truly laughable. I would skip this attraction though at night it might present a view worth the trouble. At night it is pretty from outside when lit.

Tokyo Tower is a must!!!. It's a copy of Eiffel. Go up after dark, nicer view of the city. Some part has a glass floor, so one can see the ground far below. Plenty of shops that sell snacks and souvenirs. Touristy but worth it.
Avoid public holiday to visit, coz the observatory floor is not as spacey as Eiffel. Easily filled up.

A replica of Eiffel Tower. I did'nt know of Tokyo Tower until i visit Japan. If you don't mind of paying abit to view from the 333m tower, you should visit the tower. I brought the 3 in 1 package. Consist of tower admission, 3D space, Guiness world record and wax musuem. Not worth a penny for this package. First of all, the wax musuem is small and old. Guiness world record musuem not interesting at all. 3D space is lame. I recommend to buy the tower admission tix only.

Visit about 1/2 hour before sunset for the best views. I couldn't tell you whether it was a rip-off or not as I visited the Tokyo Tower just over three years ago and can't remember how much the tickets were! But I have to say that it was one of my favourite places in Tokyo. Yes it is a replica of the Eiffel Tower and, being a tourist attraction, you can expect a certain amount of overcrowding and noise, but my companion and I managed to get a fantastic viewing spot by arriving about half an hour before sunset and..well, by being stubborn. We had a stroll around the deck to take in the panoramic views of the city, which were very impressive, then secured a spot where we could watch the sun set and take some amazing photos. We had no expectations of seeing Mt Fuji so there was no disappointment there - most of the travel guides advise that Mt Fuji is obscured throughout the majority of the year anyway so you have to be quite lucky to catch it.We descended to the floor below the observation deck where a very talented jazz singer/pianist duo were performing, which, against the backdrop of Tokyo at night seemed to suit the occasion perfectly.

Tokyo Tower. You have the option of just looking around the 4 floors which is free and has various shops and amusements on or you can pay to go up the tower to the observartory which around £10 each. You go up in a lift but when you get out there is another desk where you have to pay again to go up to the special observartoy. We didnt bother going any further. It was overcast when we were there so the views weren't great and we had previously been to the top of the Government building in Shinjuku which is free and has similar views. There is a glass floor which is good to look through. We spent quite abit of time looking around the attractions on the way down and had something to eat in an all you can eat chinese which was good value. Overall i would say its worth a visit and worth going up even if its just to say you have been up.

Not worth a penny!!!. Tokyo tower is worth seeing only from the outside. Once you pay (¥800 per person) & get to the first observatory you realize that you just wasted your money. First of all it's crowded (or feels crowded as it is a very small area), filled with screaming children, no airconditioning, hot, smelly, dark ... Instead you can make your way to "Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building" where they have two observatories (South and North). The rooms are spacious, bright, huge huge huge windows. The view is breath taking!!! And, it is free :)

Tokyo Tower at Night. Going to Tokyo Tower is one of the things I always do whenever I'm in Japan. Many other reviews say to go to the Metropolitan building for a great view of Tokyo, and I agree, but I've only gone there in the day. Going to Tokyo Tower at night is magical. All of the city is lit up and you can see the ferris wheel at Odaiba light up and give its own show. Its a bit pricey to get in, but if you go at night, there aren't that many people. It can be quite romantic. Definetly a must do, but I recommend going in the evening.

Waste of time and money. Tokyo Tower is an obvious place to visit when you're in Tokyo, but being obvious doesn't make it all that great. You'll get a better view from the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building in Shinjuku or from Roppongi Hills, and you'll spend less money and have more options for entertainment in the vicinity.

It's ok. We took a tour of the Tokyo Tower with friends. It didn't appear to be overcast but we were not able to see Mt. Fuji. We purchased the Set tickets which included the Wax Museum, Ripley's Believe it or Not, a short anime presentation and a 3-D picture museum as well as the Tokyo Tower. The 3-D museum was really cool but I would pass on Ripley's and the Wax Museum. The wax figurines were not very good if you have ever been to Madame Tussard's in London. Madame Tussard's is definitely better!My advice is to see the Tower and to try the aquarium if you want something else to do while at the Tower. Definitely bring our camera as you get to look from the floor down to the ground via a glass window in the floor.

Tokyo's version of Eiffel Tower. A must see for visitors heading for Tokyo. Though not as majestic as the Eiffel Tower of Paris, it is a Tokyo icon and it offers a bird's eye view of Tokyo. The night view of the tower is better. Lots of souvenirs and food items to buy. Plenty of stalls to choose from. It's cheaper to get the souvenirs at the shops on level one rather than on the top of the tower. And more choices too.

Tokyo Tower - A Must Visit!!!. The landmark of Tokyo, Japan. A must visit spot for all tourists visiting Tokyo.The tower offers you a great breath-taking bird-eye view of one of the greatest cities in the world - Tokyo.During a good weather day, you may be able to see Mt. Fuji from the observatory deck.Strongly recommend!!!

It's just not Blackpool. When we arrived in Tokyo we drove over the Rainbow Bridge on our way to the hotel. I remember seeing the tower and thinking "I've got to go up there".We went on a Saturday and it was busy, there was a queue outside to be allowed in to join the queue inside. Once you reached the end of the queue everyone was packed politely but firmly into one of the lifts to the first level. Once you get to the first level you can look out and see the city, or you can pay some more and join the queue to go up to the 2nd level. This isn't as fast moving as there is only one small lift but having come this far it seemed a shame not to go as high as possible.I have to admit the views from the second level were pretty spectacular. Tokyo stretches as far as the eye can see in all directions, and the views over the harbor are good. However after about 20 mins of admiring the view you feel it's time to join the queue to go down in the lift back to level 2, and then a further queue and lift to get back out.Both of the levels are enclosed is glass so it's a bit like a greenhouse when the sun shines - and it makes taking a nice photo that bit harder.All things considered it's quite expensive (I'm afraid I can't remember the exact price) and quite an effort to get up, but the views are spectacular. Unless you hear the siren call of the top of the tower very strongly you get almost as good a view from the top of the nearby world trade centre building which you can go up for a fraction of the price in about a tenth of the time.
